vignette.presentation:
26. A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of left hip pain for 2 days and an associated limp for the past 4 hours. One week ago , he had watery stools and temperatures to 37.8°C (100°F);
these symptoms resolved within 2 days . There is no history of trauma or recent immunizations . He is otherwise healthy, and his immunizations are up-to-date . He appears alert . His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F) , pulse is 90/min ,
respirations are 18/min , and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. The left hip is not swollen or erythematous , but there is pain with movement and weight bearing . His erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 28 mm/h . Ultrasonography of
the left hip joint shows a small effusion . Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

question_stem: the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The most likely diagnosis in this otherwise healthy patient is transient synovitis of the hip. Transient synovitis is an inflammatory condition involving the synovial lining of weight-bearing joints, with the hip being commonly affected. It classically presents in children recovering from a viral infection with pain on weight-bearing, antalgic gait, refusal to ambulate, tenderness over the joint, and pain elicited with range of motion. Vital signs are generally within normal limits, as are laboratory studies with the exception of increased markers of inflammation such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Antecedent viral infection has been reported in up to 30% of cases of transient synovitis. Diagnosis involves the exclusion of emergent or urgent conditions such as cellulitis, septic arthritis, osteomyelitis, and fracture. Treatment is supportive, and involves rest plus nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications, making oral ibuprofen the best choice for this patient. If there is diagnostic uncertainty, arthrocentesis to exclude septic arthritis, along with imaging to assess for osteomyelitis or fracture should be conducted.

distractor_explanations.A: is appropriate for cases of herpetic infections, such as herpes labial is, genital herpes, or varicella infections. Acyclovir is a guanosine analog that must first be activated by viral thymidine kinase, and ultimately prevents replication of the viral genome. It demonstrates no independent anti-inflammatory properties. Oral clindamycin (
distractor_explanations.B: , an antibiotic that inhibits the 50S ribosomal subunit, is appropriate for treating cases of skin and soft-tissue infections, and exhibits broad activity against many gram-positive, gram negative, and anaerobic pathogens. Intravenous ceftriaxone (
distractor_explanations.D: and intravenous vancomycin (
distractor_explanations.E: are appropriate for the inpatient treatment of bacterial infections and are a common empiric regimen used to treat meningitis. Ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin, has a broad spectrum of activity against gram-positive and gram-negative organisms, including Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a common cause of migratory polyarthritis. Vancomycin inhibits the synthesis of bacterial cell walls, and therefore has the greatest activity against gram-positive organisms. It would be an appropriate choice to treat osteomyelitis, septic arthritis, or skin and soft-tissue infections caused by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.

explanation.educational_objective: Transient synovitis is a noninfectious arthropathy that presents with pain of weight-bearing joints, often the hip, frequently following a viral infection in a child. Diagnosis involves the exclusion of emergent or urgent conditions such as cellulitis, septic arthritis, osteomyelitis, and fracture. It is best managed with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
27. A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician for an evaluation of short stature and delayed puberty . She has never had a menstrual period . Since birth , the patient's height has been below the 3rd percentile , and her weight has
been at the 3rd percentile . At the age of 10 years , x-rays of the left hand and wrist showed that bone age was equal to chronologic age . Her mother, who is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall , had menarche at the age of 12 years . Her father
is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall. The patient is 147 cm (4 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (120 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m 2 Her pulse is 76/min , and blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple nevi over the face and trunk .
•
There is bilateral pedal edema . Breast development is Tanner stage 1, and pubic hair development is Tanner stage 1. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Gonadal dysgenesis 45, X (Turner syndrome) results from monosomy of the X chromosome and presents with characteristic physical features including short stature, a wide webbed neck, a broad chest with widely spaced nipples, and multiple melanocytic nevi. Short stature in patients with Turner syndrome likely results from haploinsufficiency of the short stature homeobox gene on the X chromosome. Delayed development of secondary sexual characteristics is common, such as with the Tanner Stage 1 breast and pubic hair development in this patient. Primary amenorrhea is also a common finding. Patients with Turner syndrome may also present with bicuspid aortic valve, aortic coarctation, or a fused kidney.

distractor_explanations.A: may occur in pediatric patients and more commonly presents with symptoms of hypothyroidism. Thyroid dysfunction is less likely to result in delayed development of secondary sexual characteristics. Constitutional short stature (
distractor_explanations.B: may lead to short stature during childhood and adolescence but usually results in normal adult stature. This diagnosis would not account for the patient's finding of primary amenorrhea and delayed sexual development. Craniopharyngioma (
distractor_explanations.C: may lead to acquired deficiency of growth hormone. However, other accompanying findings are usually encountered, such as headache, vomiting, and visual field defects. Familial short stature (
distractor_explanations.D: is a common cause of short stature, but the child's expected height should be relatively similar to that of her parents. This child is both significantly shorter than both parents and has other findings, such as primary amenorrhea and delayed sexual development that would not be explained by this diagnosis. Idiopathic hypopituitarism (
distractor_explanations.F: may result in deficiency of one or several pituitary hormones, but it is a diagnosis requiring laboratory investigation and would not present with the remaining characteristic physical examination findings of Turner syndrome.

Short stature in patients with Turner syndrome likely results from haploinsufficiency of the short stature homeobox gene on the X chromosome. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
28. A 3-year-old boy is brought for a well-child examination . His mother states that his belly seems big. His vital signs are within normal limits . Examination shows aniridia . There is a palpable mass in the right flank . The remainder of
the examination shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Measurement of urine vanillylmandelic acid and homovanillic acid concentrations

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Nephroblastoma, or Wilms tumor, is the most common renal malignancy in childhood as a result of mutations in tumor suppressor genes WT1 or WT2. It is characterized by a large, often palpable, unilateral flank mass. Patients can be asymptomatic or have symptoms of abdominal pain or hematuria. Nephroblastoma can also be associated with congenital anomalies such as hemihypertrophy, genitourinary abnormalities, and aniridia. The preferred initial diagnostic study is typically abdominal ultrasonography to evaluate the abdominal mass. Other masses that can be differentiated from nephroblastoma include hydronephrosis and polycystic kidney disease. If nephroblastoma is diagnosed, further imaging can be done to further evaluate any tumor infiltration and the full extent of the mass.

distractor_explanations.A: can be performed in the evaluation of pheochromocytoma or neuroblastoma. Measurement of urine vanillylmandelic acid and homovanillic acid concentrations (
distractor_explanations.B: is also performed in the evaluation of pheochromocytoma. Pheochromocytoma presents with episodic headaches, sweating, palpitations, tremors, agitation, tachycardia, tachypnea, and treatment-refractory hypertension. It is a common tumor of the adrenal medulla and is marked by the functional secretion of epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine, which cause episodic hyperadrenergic symptoms. X-ray of the abdomen (
distractor_explanations.C: can be performed to evaluate for bowel obstruction, swallowed foreign body, necrotizing enterocolitis, or constipation. An x-ray is not as sensitive as a CT scan and has little utility in the evaluation of abdominal masses. Chest imaging can elucidate whether there are any lung metastases. An x-ray of the chest (
distractor_explanations.D: would be less sensitive for this purpose, and the abdominal mass should be first evaluated.

29. An 11-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 1-day history of lethargy, mild abdominal pain, and dark urine . He had a sore throat and an upper respiratory tract infection 10 days ago that resolved spontaneously .
His pulse is 90/min , respirations are 20/min , and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Examination shows slight swelling around the eyes . Urinalysis shows light brown urine with RBC and granular casts . Which of the following is
the most likely mechanism for these findings?

Bacterial infiltration of the epithelial cells

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is a type of nephritic syndrome characterized by peripheral and periorbital edema, dark-colored urine, hypertension, acute kidney injury, and proteinuria following an infection with Streptococcus pyogenes (group A). The pathogenesis of PSGN involves streptococcal antigens complexing with antibodies, deposition of immune complexes in the glomerular basement membrane, and subsequent complement activation and inflammation. Neutrophilic infiltration of the glomerular tuft can be seen in PSGN. Management of PSGN is supportive and focused on treating complications such as volume overload and hypertension with diuretics and antihypertensive medications. Rarely, severe kidney injury secondary to PSGN may require kidney replacement therapy.

distractor_explanations.C: . Destruction of tubular epithelial cells (
distractor_explanations.D: describes the pathophysiology of acute tubular necrosis. Acute tubular necrosis typically occurs following an ischemic (
distractor_explanations.E: or nephrotoxic insult to the kidneys, which results in necrosis of the tubular epithelium. Granular, muddy brown casts are typical on urinalysis.

vignette.presentation:
30. A 2370-g (5-lb 3-oz) newborn is delivered at term to a 37-year-old primigravid woman who had limited prenatal care . The mother drank one to two beers daily but did not use any illicit drugs . The newborn appears vigorous and is
not cyanotic . Examination shows a prominent occiput , narrow palpebral fissures , a small recessed mandible , and a short sternum . The hands are clenched with the index finger folded over the middle finger and the small finger
folded over the ring finger . There is a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur that is heard best at the lower left sternal border . The abdomen is prominent and soft ; there is no hepatosplenomegaly . Peripheral pulses are normal. There is
generalized hypertonia . Deep tendon reflexes are present. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this newborn's low birth weight?

question_stem: the most likely explanation for this newborn's low birth weight?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: lntussusception occurs when a segment of bowel telescopes into an adjacent segment, resulting in colicky abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and potential bloody, mucoid stools. Classically, it presents in an infant or young child with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain often punctuated by asymptomatic periods. lntussusception typically occurs as a result of the presence of a pathologic lead point, often lymphoid hyperplasia, lymphadenopathy, Meckel diverticulum, stricture, or malignancy, which acts to draw one segment of bowel into an adjacent segment during peristalsis. If the intussusception self-resolves, there may be no symptoms. If it does not resolve, traction on mesenteric vessels can result in hypoperfusion of the segment with resultant inflammation, hemorrhage, obstruction, and pain. It may be detected on physical examination as an elongated mass, often in the right upper quadrant. Diagnosis consists of clinical history and physical examination and is supported by imaging. Ultrasonography evaluation is preferred in young children and will show telescoping interposed bowel segments in longitudinal orientation or a targetoid appearance in transverse orientation. Treatment of an ileocolic intussusception requires the administration of a contrast enema, which decreases the intussusception. Contrast enema is both diagnostic and therapeutic in this setting. Surgery may be required in cases where there is repetitive failure of the enema to decrease the intussusception or if the patient presents with symptoms concerning for bowel necrosis or perforation.

distractor_explanations.A: describes congenital joint contractures, which result in impaired joint movement and function and may lead to muscle atrophy. Congenital infection (
distractor_explanations.B: can occur with multiple viruses such as cytomegalovirus (CMV), herpes simplex virus (HSV), rubella, measles, or parvovirus. Each congenital viral infection results in different congenital abnormalities. HSV can cause both cutaneous herpetic lesions and systemic manifestations like meningoencephalitis. Congenital infection with CMV manifests as hearing loss, seizures, a petechial rash, intracranial calcifications, organomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. Neonates with congenital rubella infection exhibit a classic triad of cataracts, sensorineural deafness, and congenital heart disease. Exposure to alcohol in utero (
distractor_explanations.C: results in fetal alcohol syndrome, which can cause intellectual disability and congenital abnormalities such as microcephaly, facial abnormalities (eg, thin vermillion border, small palpebral fissures), and heart defects. Uteroplacental insufficiency (
distractor_explanations.E: describes insufficient blood flow to the placenta, abnormal placenta, or inability of the placenta to deliver sufficient nutrients to the fetus during pregnancy. It can result in a variety of disorders including fetal hypoglycemia, oligohydramnios, intrauterine growth restriction, or maternal complications including preeclampsia, miscarriage, or stillbirth.

explanation.educational_objective: Trisomy 18, also known as Edwards syndrome, presents with characteristic physical features including intellectual disability, a prominent occiput, low-set ears, micrognathia, clenched overlapping fingers, and feet with prominent calcanei and convexly rounded soles. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
32. A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician because he is concerned that he has not had to begin shaving . He says all of his friends have begun shaving . He first noticed pubic hair development 6 months ago . He is at the 25th
percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. Examination shows mild bilateral gynecomastia . Genital and pubic hair development is Tanner stage 2. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities .
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Puberty in boys typically follows a predictable course of gonadarche (enlargement of the testes), followed by pubarche (pubic hair), followed by adrenarche (axillary hair, facial hair, voice changes), followed by a growth spurt. This differs from the process in girls, which proceeds from thelarche (breast buds) to pubarche to growth spurt and finally menarche. In boys, delayed puberty is defined as the absence of testicular enlargement or secondary sexual characteristics at the age of 14 years. The most common cause of delayed puberty is constitutional delay of growth and puberty (CDGP), accounting for approximately 50% of cases, a normal variant. In CDGP, there is a transient defect in the production of gonadotropin-releasing hormone with resultant delay in the stimulation of pituitary production of follicle-stimulating hormone and luteinizing hormone. CDGP tends to be familial with many members of the same family undergoing late puberty compared with peers. In this case, the patient has undergone gonadarche (indicated by his Tanner stage 2 genital development) and pubarche but has not yet undergone adrenarche. Thus, while delayed, the sequence of his procession through the steps of puberty is appropriate and he can be reassured that his development will continue to progress.

distractor_explanations.B: is unnecessary in this case because the patient is progressing through the stages of puberty as expected. If his puberty did not continue to progress, testosterone measurement could be used to differentiate CDGP from another pathology. Mild bilateral gynecomastia can be normal in early puberty as a result of the small increase in extragonadal production of estrogen relative to the amount of testosterone being produced. Urine toxicology screening (
distractor_explanations.C: would be appropriate if there was a suspicion for drug use inducing gynecomastia, of which marijuana is the most common recreational drug. Breast biopsy (
distractor_explanations.E: would be indicated if the breast enlargement was caused by a nodule or mass rather than true gynecomastia. If delayed puberty were accompanied by neurologic findings or suspected to be caused by a process involving the brain such as a pituitary adenoma, MRI of the brain, not CT scan of the head (
distractor_explanations.D: , would be indicated. Neither imaging modality is necessary in this case.

explanation.educational_objective: In boys, puberty follows a predictable course of gonadarche, pubarche, and growth spurt. Delayed puberty is defined as the absence of testicular enlargement or secondary sexual characteristics at the age of 14 years and is most commonly caused by constitutional delay of growth and puberty. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
33. A previously healthy 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-week history of mild itching of his head and scattered areas of hair loss on his scalp . Examination shows several small oval areas of alopecia over
the posterior scalp with numerous hairs broken off close to the scalp . Several small , occipital , nontender lymph nodes are palpated . The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most
likely causal organism?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp that is common in children. It presents as scaly patches with alopecia, patches of alopecia with black dots that represent broken hairs, and cervical lymphadenopathy. The most common causal organism is Trichophyton tonsurans, although infections can also be caused by other Trichophyton species, Microsporum species, and Epidermophyton species. A potassium hydroxide preparation of a skin scraping will show fungal hyphae or spores. It is treated with oral antifungals, such as griseofulvin or terbinafine.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Varicella zoster, also known as human herpesvirus-3, is transmitted via respiratory secretions and direct contact with infected skin lesions. It causes the disease chickenpox in immunocompetent children and can cause encephalitis and pneumonia in immunosuppressed children. The rash associated with chickenpox typically persists for 1 to 2 weeks. Varicella is uncommon in infancy and may occur as an opportunistic infection in infants with HIV or as an immunocompromising condition impairing T lymphocytes. As with many viral infections, T lymphocyte function is an essential component of host defense and is impaired in the setting of HIV infection. Persistence of symptoms for 1 month is suggestive of underlying T-lymphocyte immunodeficiency. Infants with immunodeficiency are at a greater risk for severe consequences of varicella infection, including end organ involvement.

distractor_explanations.A: occurs in several immunodeficiencies such as X-linked agammaglobulinemia and common variable immunodeficiency. Affected infants demonstrate recurrent infections with both bacterial and viral organisms. Impaired complement function (
distractor_explanations.B: occurs in several complement disorders. Patients with deficient function of complement are at increased risk for infection with encapsulated bacterial organisms. Impaired neutrophil adhesion (
distractor_explanations.C: occurs in leukocyte adhesion deficiency. Patients present with recurrent skin and mucosal infections, absent pus, and delayed separation of the umbilical cord. Impaired neutrophil chemotaxis (
distractor_explanations.D: occurs in Chediak-Higashi syndrome, which presents with albinism, peripheral neuropathy, and recurrent pyogenic infections. Neutrophil oxidation burst (
distractor_explanations.F: defects occur in chronic granulomatous disease, which presents with recurrent infections with organisms possessing catalase, such as Staphylococcus aureus.

explanation.educational_objective: Defense against varicella zoster virus relies on T lymphocyte function, which is impaired in the setting of HIV infection and T-lymphocyte immunodeficiency. appears severely dehydrated . There is a fruity odor to her breath. She is at the 75th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min , and blood
pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Capillary refill time is 4 seconds , and capillary blood glucose concentration is greater than 500 mg/dl . Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Intravenous administration of 20 ml/kg of 5% dextrose in water
Intravenous administration of 20 ml/kg of 0.9% saline
Intravenous administration of 20 ml/kg of lactated Ringer solution with 40 mEq/L of potassium chloride
Intravenous administration of 0.1 U/h of regular insulin
Continuous intravenous administration of 0.1 U/h of regular insulin

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) occurs as a result of the accumulation of serum ketones such as ~-hydroxybutyric acid, acetoacetic acid, and acetone in the setting of deficient insulin signaling. Dysregulated fatty acid degradation and ketone synthesis occurs as a result of the relative state of starvation created through absent insulin signaling. Extracellular hyperglycemia creates an osmotic effect resulting in the shift of fluid from the intracellular to the extracellular space with accompanying profuse osmotic diuresis and intracellular volume loss. Patients present with signs and symptoms including tachycardia, tachypnea, fatigue, polyuria, shortness of breath, Kussmaul respiration, and diffuse abdominal discomfort. Laboratory evaluation typically shows increased concentrations of glucose, ketones, and a high anion-gap metabolic acidosis caused by the accumulation of unmeasured anions (ketones, lactic acid) in serum. Treatment is through the replacement of insulin, volume repletion, correction of electrolyte abnormalities, and treatment of any precipitating conditions. Insulin is typically repleted at an initial dose of 0.1 U/kg/hour by intravenous infusion. Volume resuscitation with 0.9% saline is essential to restore intracellular fluid volume and lower the extracellular glucose concentration and is the initial step in the management of DKA even prior to insulin administration. Administering insulin prior to knowing the serum potassium concentration can result in life-threatening hypokalemia.

distractor_explanations.A: would worsen this patient's profound hyperglycemia. 0.9% saline is a more appropriate initial resuscitation fluid. Intravenous administration of 20 ml/kg of lactated Ringer solution with 40 mEq/L of potassium chloride (
distractor_explanations.C: may be acceptable once the patient's potassium concentration is known; however, in DKA, derangements in potassium can include hypo- or hyperkalemia. Infusing a fluid with potassium may result in worsening of unknown derangements with potentially life-threatening dysrhythmias. Administration of regular insulin either via intravenous dose at 0.1 U/h (
distractor_explanations.D: or via continuous intravenous infusion at 0.1 U/h (
distractor_explanations.E: is not the best

Restoration of fluid balance is an essential step in the emergent management of diabetic ketoacidosis and is best accomplished with the intravenous administration of 0.9% saline. r " , r-- r ,

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Measles (rubeola) virus is a highly contagious paramyxovirus that causes the disease measles, which is associated with acute febrile illness and potentially severe sequelae. It is more common in children than adults. It characteristically presents with a prodromal fever along with cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and a confluent maculopapular rash that starts at the head/neck and spreads to the trunk, excluding the palms and soles. Physical examination may show bright red macules with a bluish-white center on the buccal mucosa (Koplik spots) and lymphadenopathy. Treatment is supportive. Vitamin A deficiency is associated with severe disease and complications, and supplementation should be provided, especially in children who are malnourished. Complications of measles include subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (a neurodegenerative disease associated with intellectual regression, personality changes, motor deterioration, seizures, and premature death), encephalitis, and giant cell pneumonia.

distractor_explanations.A: results in the early development of panacinar emphysema and cirrhosis. It is a hereditary disease resulting from misfolding of arantitrypsin. The lack of functional arantitrypsin release results in an imbalance of proteases and antiproteases in the lung parenchyma, resulting in the destruction of alveolar septa and development of panacinar emphysema. Asthma (
distractor_explanations.B: is characterized by reversible obstruction to airflow caused by the spasm of smooth muscle in the bronchi and small airways, and may present with dyspnea, wheezing, or chronic nonproductive cough. It is often triggered by an allergen (eg, smoke, pollen), exercise, or temperature change. It may be associated with progressive reactive airway remodeling over time. The lack of response to inhaled 13- adrenergic agonists and oral prednisone in this patient do not support the diagnosis of asthma. Congenital emphysema (
distractor_explanations.D: is a rare pulmonary disorder caused by disrupted embryonic bronchopulmonary development and is characterized by air trapping and lung hyperinflation, which can be visualized on chest imaging. The severity of disease varies widely and may be asymptomatic until adulthood or present in the newborn with respiratory distress. Cystic fibrosis (
distractor_explanations.E: is a clinical syndrome resulting from defects in the CFTR gene, leading to a deficiency in a chloride channel that secretes chloride in the lungs and gastrointestinal tract and reabsorbs chloride in sweat glands. Cystic fibrosis is associated with bronchiectasis because of the risk for recurrent pulmonary infections. The absence of other findings associated with cystic fibrosis, such as pancreatic insufficiency, diarrhea, malnutrition, and weight loss, argue against cystic fibrosis as the cause of this patient's bronchiectasis.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Neonatal jaundice is defined as an increased bilirubin concentration (greater than 5 mg/dl), which results from either increased hemolysis {bilirubin generation) or decreased bilirubin conjugation or excretion. Hyperbilirubinemia can be divided into direct and indirect forms in which either conjugated or unconjugated bilirubin accumulate, respectively. It can also be divided into physiologic and pathologic forms. Features of physiologic jaundice include development after 24 hours of life, a rate of bilirubin rise of less than 0.5 mg/dl daily, a maximum peak of 14 to 15 mg/dl, and a predominance of indirect bilirubin (greater than 90%). In contrast, jaundice within the first 24 hours of life {which rises faster than 0.5 mg/dl per hour), a predominance of direct bilirubin, and persistence beyond 2 weeks would suggest a pathologic cause. Newborn physiologic jaundice, also termed benign neonatal hyperbilirubinemia, occurs in nearly all newborns and is caused by the increased breakdown of red blood cells and thus generation of bilirubin, the immature liver metabolism of bilirubin, and the increased enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin. These features taken together cause an indirect hyperbilirubinemia to develop. Neonatal hyperbilirubinemia is closely monitored in order to prevent kernicterus, which refers to the deposition of bilirubin in the basal ganglia, pons, and cerebellum. This can occur at bilirubin concentrations of 25 to 30 mg/dl. Treatment of the underlying cause of the jaundice and phototherapy for unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia or exchange transfusion prevents this potentially fatal consequence. lncorrectAnswers:A, B, C, D, and F. ABO isoimmunization {Choice A) occurs when maternal lgG antibodies to fetal red blood cell antigens cause either fetal or neonatal destruction of these red blood cells. Bilirubin production is increased, and an indirect hyperbilirubinemia ensues. This cause of neonatal jaundice will present with pathologic findings such as an early presentation and rapid rate of rise, neither of which are present in this case. Biliary obstruction {Choice B) caused by biliary atresia is a common cause of direct hyperbilirubinemia. In congenital biliary atresia, the common bile duct is occluded or atretic and bile is unable to pass into the duodenum. Dehydration {Choice C) is the mechanism behind breastfeeding jaundice. In the first week of life, as a breastfeeding mother's milk begins to establish, the infant may become dehydrated. Dehydration leads to increased enterohepatic circulation and reabsorption of bilirubin, resulting in indirect hyperbilirubinemia. In this case, the infant's consistent wet diapers and stools argue against a dehydrated state. Erythrocyte enzyme defect {Choice D) such as glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency causes increased hemolysis of red blood cells and a subsequent increase in unconjugated bilirubin. explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's immunocompromise and vesicular eruption is consistent with reactivation of varicella zoster virus in the form of herpes zoster infection. Varicella zoster virus infection (VZV), also known as human herpesvirus-3 (HHV-3), is transmitted via respiratory secretions and direct contact with infected skin lesions. It causes two diseases: varicella and herpes zoster. Varicella causes chickenpox in immunocompetent children which is characterized by a pruritic, asynchronous rash with fluid-filled vesicles that crust. The vesicles heal as crusted papules and lesions are in various stages of healing. Varicella can cause encephalitis and pneumonia in immunosuppressed patients, such as an individual being treated with chemotherapy. Herpes zoster is caused by the recurrence of VZV after it has been reactivated from its dormancy in the dorsal root ganglion of a spinal nerve. It commonly presents as a unilateral, dermatomal erythematous patch with overlying clear to yellow, grouped vesicles. It can be associated with neuropathic pain which can precede and outlast the rash. However, post-herpetic neuralgia is more common in elderly patients than pediatric patients. The thoracic spinal nerves and trigeminal nerve are particularly common distributions of reactivation. Treatment for herpetic infections, including herpes zoster infections, involves medications that inhibit viral DNA polymerase, classically by guanosine analogs such as acyclovir, valacyclovir, and famciclovir.

distractor_explanations.A: is an enterovirus which causes hand, foot, and mouth disease. This presents with painful oval-shaped vesicles on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa. Coxsackievirus is also the cause of herpangina, an infection of the posterior pharynx which usually involves the tonsils, soft palate, and uvula. Examination of these sites shows erythema caused by hyperemia and yellow to gray papulovesicular lesions. Herpes simplex virus (
distractor_explanations.B: is typically transmitted through contact with infected skin or mucosal surfaces, and can present with a variety of symptoms, including genital herpes, herpes labialis, herpetic whitlow, encephalitis, esophagitis, and keratoconjunctivitis. This patient's dermatomal distribution favors herpes zoster over a cutaneous herpes simplex virus infection. Leukemic relapse (
distractor_explanations.D: can present with a rash in the form of leukemia cutis. Leukemia cutis is caused by infiltration of the epidermis and dermis with leukemic cells. It has a range of presentations, but firm papules or subcutaneous nodules, not vesicles, are most common. Toxic drug reaction (
distractor_explanations.E: , or toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), is a severe cutaneous drug reaction which has a high mortality rate. It is characterized by large areas of dusky erythema with desquamation of the epidermis. It is often complicated by infection of the denuded areas of skin. The confinement of small vesicles to a single dermatome without spreading would be highly uncharacteristic of TEN.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Juvenile arthritis (juvenile idiopathic arthritis, or JIA) occurs before the age of 16 and is a common rheumatic disease among children. The disease has an autoimmune cause and is characterized by joint pain and inflammation. Patients commonly exhibit extra-articular manifestations such as uveitis, lymphadenopathy, and rash. There are a variety of sub-categories of JIA. For example, oligoarticular disease is characterized by the involvement of fewer than five joints (typically large joints such as the knee) and antinuclear antibody (ANA) positivity; polyarticular disease is characterized by involvement of greater than five joints (typically both large and small joints such as the interphalangeal joints), uveitis, and negative ANA titers, and systemic disease (also known as juvenile onset Still disease) is characterized by variable joint involvement, rash, quotidian fever, and serositis. Diagnosis is often difficult and is based on a combination of characteristic clinical findings and suggestive laboratory tests, such as ANA, rheumatoid factor, anti-citrullinated peptide, and inflammatory tests such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate. There is no single, confirmatory laboratory test for JIA. Treatment modalities include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, disease modifying antirheumatic medications such as methotrexate, and biologic agents.

distractor_explanations.C: is most commonly bacterial and presents with the rapid onset of fever, joint swelling, erythema, pain, tenderness with range of motion, inability to bear weight, and leukocytosis. Arthrocentesis typically shows bacteria on Gram stain, most often Gram-positive organisms, and leukocyte count is greater than or equal to 50,000/mm 3 with a neutrophilic predominance. Tear of the anterior cruciate ligament (
distractor_explanations.D: commonly presents as an acute injury in athletes when attempting rapid changes in direction upon a planted foot. Patients often report an audible pop when the injury is sustained and experience acute onset of pain, joint swelling, and instability. Tibia vara (
distractor_explanations.E: refers to an outward-bowing deformity of the tibia. It commonly occurs in children with vitamin D deficiency (rickets) or Blount disease. It does not typically manifest with joint swelling.

Diagnosis is made by a combination of characteristic clinical and laboratory findings. r " , r-- r ,

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the hyperkalemia?

question_stem: the most likely explanation for the hyperkalemia?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) typically occurs in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus as a result of increased insulin requirements during times of physiologic stress (eg, infection) or insulin nonadherence. DKA occurs as a result of the accumulation of serum ketones in the setting of deficient insulin signaling. Dysregulated fatty acid degradation and ketone synthesis occurs because of the relative state of starvation created through absent insulin signaling. Patients may present with complaints of fatigue, polyuria, shortness of breath, and diffuse abdominal discomfort. Vital signs may show tachycardia and tachypnea. Laboratory studies typically show increased glucose and ketone concentrations, metabolic acidosis, and a high anion-gap caused by the accumulation of unmeasured anions in serum. In metabolic acidosis, excess hydrogen ions are transported into the cell in exchange for potassium ions to maintain electroneutrality. Insulin promotes intracellular potassium entry, and in DKA, insulin deficiency contributes to the excess cellular shift of potassium to the extracellular space resulting in hyperkalemia despite decreased concentrations of total body potassium as a result of excess urinary excretion. Treatment is through replacement of insulin, volume repletion, correction of electrolyte abnormalities, and treatment of any precipitating conditions. lncorrectAnswers:A, C, D, and E. Adrenal insufficiency (Choice A) refers to insufficient production of hormones from the adrenal cortex, which include aldosterone and cortisol; sex hormone deficiency may also be present. Primary adrenal insufficiency can present with deficiencies in both aldosterone and cortisol, whereas secondary and tertiary adrenal insufficiency tend to affect cortisol only. Insufficient aldosterone production leads to hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. Insufficient cortisol can lead to hypoglycemia, hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, and depressed mental status. In this patient, DKA is more likely given his history of type 1 diabetes, metabolic acidosis, and hyperglycemia. Excessive potassium intake (Choice C) would be unlikely to cause hyperkalemia in this patient. Kidney potassium filtration typically regulates serum potassium within a normal range, but this can be impaired in end stage kidney disease. In DKA, the kidney excretion of potassium is increased because of osmotic diuresis. Hyperkalemia in this case is as a result of the extracellular shift of potassium and deficient insulin signaling. Hemolysis (Choice D) can result in hyperkalemia because of the release of intracellular potassium into the serum. DKA is unlikely to cause hemolysis. Hemolytic anemia may present with jaundice and increased bilirubin. Respiratory acidosis (Choice E) would be the opposite of what is expected in a patient with DKA. In DKA, metabolic acidosis leads to compensatory respiratory alkalosis. Kussmaul respirations, which are rapid and deep, are a classic physical examination finding.
explanation.educational_objective: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) typically occurs in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus as a result of increased insulin requirements during times of physiologic stress (eg, infection) or insulin r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation: 4. While being evaluated for a cardiac murmur , a 12-year-old boy is noted to have bilateral gynecomastia . His sexual development is Tanner stage 3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Evaluate his brothers for this finding
Privately tell his parents about the finding
Reassure him that this is normal

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Gynecomastia refers to an increase in the amount of glandular breast tissue in males, and it is common during puberty. Pubertal gynecomastia is caused by a disruption in the normal balance of androgens and estrogens and is common in boys aged 12 to 14 years old, typically when they have a sexual maturity rating of 3, as in this patient. The increased concentrations of estrogen are caused by the conversion of androstenedione and testosterone to estrone and estradiol. On physical examination, gynecomastia may be tender to palpation. Results of laboratory studies will be within reference ranges in pubertal gynecomastia but could be used to delineate other causes of gynecomastia. These other causes include medications (eg, spironolactone, ketoconazole, antiandrogen therapy), liver cirrhosis, germ cell tumors, hypogonadism, and hyperthyroidism. Physiologic gynecomastia typically self-resolves but medical and surgical options exist for symptomatic patients, such as aromatase inhibitors and liposuction. As this patient has no signs to suggest pathologic gynecomastia, reassurance is appropriate.

distractor_explanations.A: may be useful in the evaluation of suspected Cushing syndrome (high concentrations of baseline cortisol) or Addison disease (deficiency of cortisol). Cushing syndrome presents with weight gain, fatigue, truncal obesity, fat redistribution, hirsutism, and abdominal striae, whereas Addison disease presents with hypotension, hypoglycemia, hyperpigmentation, and abdominal pain. Neither present with gynecomastia as a direct result, though truncal obesity may resemble it in Cushing syndrome (or in Cushing disease). Measuring serum gonadotropin concentrations (
distractor_explanations.B: may be useful in the evaluation of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, such as Klinefelter syndrome, which can present with gynecomastia. However, patients with Klinefelter syndrome typically have testicular atrophy, tall stature, and long extremities, which this patient does not exhibit. Evaluating his brother for this finding (
distractor_explanations.C: may be useful if the gynecomastia was because of a hereditary disorder, such as partial androgen insensitivity or aromatase excess. However, this patient is presenting with mild gynecomastia associated with puberty, making physiologic gynecomastia more likely. Privately telling his parents about the finding (
distractor_explanations.D: is inappropriate, as the condition is benign, and the patient should be included in health conversations regarding his body.

explanation.educational_objective: Physiologic pubertal gynecomastia is a benign proliferation of glandular breast tissue in boys aged 12 to 14 years, most commonly during at the sexual maturity rating of 3 during puberty. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Physiologic pubertal gynecomastia is a benign proliferation of glandular breast tissue in boys aged 12 to 14 years, most commonly during at the sexual maturity rating of 3 during puberty. r " , r-- r

vignette.presentation:
5. A 4-month-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination . She is breast-feeding successfully and has been in good health . She is able to roll from her
stomach to her back , and she looks around with curiosity , coos , and orients to voice . Her parents are concerned about a lesion on her left thigh that has become
darker since birth . The patient appears well. She is at the 50th percentile for length and weight. Examination of the left thigh shows the brown lesion seen in the
photograph. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Congenital melanocytic nevus (CMN) is a benign proliferation of melanocytes that is present from birth. Compared to normal skin, within a nevus the melanocytes are clustered into nests. Nests are either located in the basal layer of the epidermis, in the dermis, or both. Compared to acquired nevi, CMN are often larger and darker. CMN are classified by their size: small (<1.5 cm), medium (1.5-20 cm), large (>20-40 cm), and giant (>40 cm). Large and giant CMN are at risk for malignant transformation. In this case, the CMN is symmetrical, uniform in color and thickness, and appears to have a rough texture. Hair is present on the inferior aspect which is common in CMN. CMN should be routinely monitored by a dermatologist. If an area within the CMN develops increased thickness or change in color, it should be biopsied to evaluate for presence of melanoma. Provided the CMN does not develop melanoma, they are benign. However, they can be associated with psychological morbidity if they are located in cosmetically sensitive areas of the body and depending on their size. Complete surgical excision of large or giant CMN is usually impossible, but particularly bothersome areas may be excised to improve function and cosmesis.

distractor_explanations.B: describe cafe-au-lait spots. A cafe-au-lait spot is characterized by a tan to dark brown, uniformly pigmented macule or patch often seen at birth or noticed in early childhood. This lesion, in contrast, is a dark brown plaque with the presence of hair at the inferior aspect. It may be asymmetrical or have an irregular border. It represents a focal increase in melanin production rather than an increased number of melanocytes or any form of malignancy. While numerous cafe-au-lait spots suggest an underlying genetic disease, a single lesion is a normal finding. Macular stain (
distractor_explanations.C: , port-wine stain (
distractor_explanations.D: , and superficial hemangioma (
distractor_explanations.E: are all vascular lesions and will appear red to purple rather than brown to black. Macular stains, or nevi flammeus, are common red patches present on the forehead and posterior neck at birth. Port-wine stain and nevus flammeus are both capillary malformations while superficial hemangioma is a benign proliferation of capillary sized vessels. These lesions are benign, but superficial hemangiomas may ulcerate and bleed. Both port-wine stains and superficial hemangiomas can be treated with laser therapy to decrease the size and color if desired. Nevus flammeus on the forehead and eyelids commonly resolves and those on the posterior neck usually fade but do not completely disappear.

explanation.educational_objective: Congenital melanocytic nevus (CMN) is a benign proliferation of melanocytes that is present from birth. Compared to acquired nevi, CMN are often larger and darker. Hair may be present. There is an increased risk for malignant transformation in large or giant CMN and regular monitoring should be performed. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
6. A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a scaly, pruritic rash on intertriginous areas of her elbows and knees that worsens in the spring and the fall ; it often appears in conjunction with episodes of respiratory
distress and wheezing . Treatment with which of the following is the most effective short-term treatment of the rash?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Atopic dermatitis, or eczema, is a chronic pruritic inflammatory skin disease common in children. The diagnosis of atopic dermatitis is made based on clinical symptoms. Pruritus must be present in addition to three of the following: current or past flexural eczema, history of asthma or hay fever, or presence of dry skin within the past year. The rash is initially characterized by erythematous papules and vesicles with exudates and crusting. With chronic scratching, they become dry, scaly, and excoriated in a process called lichenification. This patient's flexural dermatitis and apparent asthma and hay fever suggest a diagnosis of atopic dermatitis. Treatment of atopic dermatitis begins with gentle skin care: minimizing long baths in warm water which causes drying of the skin, avoiding products with fragrance, and use of bland moisturizers such as petroleum jelly daily. Flares of eczema are treated with mild to moderate potency topical corticosteroids, such as triamcinolone. In children, a moderate potency topical corticosteroid should not be used consistently for over 2 to 3 weeks because of the potential of systemic absorption.

distractor_explanations.A: is a topical anti-fungal used to treat superficial dermatophyte infections such as tinea pedis and tinea corporis. Griseofulvin (
distractor_explanations.C: is a systemic antifungal used to treat tinea capitis in children. While the bacterial and fungal microbiome do play a role in the development and treatment of atopic dermatitis, triamcinolone is a more effective short-term treatment of eczema. Coal tar (
distractor_explanations.B: is a topical remedy used in psoriasis, not eczema. Its mechanism is not fully elucidated, but it is thought to be anti-inflammatory and anti-proliferative to the epidermis. Lindane (
distractor_explanations.D: is an antiparasitic agent which in the past has been used to treat lice infestation. However, it is no longer used given the relatively high incidence of neurologic toxicity. This is especially of concern in young children, who have a lower body surface area to volume ratio.

explanation.educational_objective: Atopic dermatitis, or eczema, is characterized by pruritus and recurrent episodes of dermatitis on the flexural surfaces of children. It is commonly seen in concert with asthma and allergies (food or seasonal), which form the atopic triad. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
7. A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination 2 weeks after being treated for an ear infection . He has had recurrent ear infections , sinusitis , and two episodes of bacterial pneumonia since birth . Over the
past year, he has undergone placement of two sets of tympanostomy tubes for otitis media . His mother is HIV negative . He currently takes no medications . He is at the 25th percentile for height and weight. Examination shows no
abnormalities except for small anterior cervical lymph nodes . Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of disease?

question_stem: the most likely mechanism of disease?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: lgA deficiency is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms. Selective lgA deficiency describes a decreased or absent concentration of circulating lgA with normal concentrations of lgG, and normal or increased concentrations of lgM. lgA is critical for immune health and functions in two primary ways. First, lgA binds pathogen surface antigens targeting them for opsonization, complement activation, and phagocytosis. Second, lgA coats mucosal surfaces and prevents colonization, adhesion, and invasion by pathogenic microorganisms. lmmunoglobulins are produced by plasma cells, which are terminally differentiated B lymphocytes; as a result, most causal deficiencies are hypothesized to be related to B lymphocyte abnormalities. Despite this, there is clinical heterogeneity in the severity of lgA deficiency. Some patients remain asymptomatic while others suffer from recurrent sinopulmonary infections or otitis media, as is the case for this patient. In younger patients with severe deficiency, failure to thrive is common. Anaphylactic reactions to blood products such as plasma (which contain donor immunoglobulin) are classic but uncommon, as not all patients with lgA deficiency have reactions to blood products. Such severe reactions are most common in patients with undetectable concentrations of lgA; these reactions occur because of the presence of preformed antibodies against lgA, which is a non-native protein in these patients, and thus, a target of immune activation.

distractor_explanations.B: describes several syndromes, one of which is hyperimmunoglobulinemia E syndrome. These patients have abnormal Th T-lymphocyte function and thus, impaired release of IL-17, a 17 potent agent for neutrophil chemotaxis. These patients present with recurrent abscesses with minimal inflammation. Impaired respiratory burst (
distractor_explanations.C: describes chronic granulomatous disease, which is caused by a deficiency in NADPH oxidase, an enzyme used to generate hydrogen peroxide and hypochlorous acid. These molecules are typically used to kill bacteria intracellularly. Patients present with recurrent pyogenic infections with catalase-positive organisms such as Staphylococcus aureus, with normal concentrations of leukocytes and immunoglobulins. Splenic dysfunction (
distractor_explanations.D: can be the consequence of splenectomy or can occur in diseases such as sickle cell disease, where patients become functionally asplenic early in the course of disease. This predisposes to infection with encapsulated organisms such as Haemophi/us influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Streptococcus pneumoniae. lgA deficiency is the more likely diagnosis for this patient. T-lymphocyte dysfunction (
distractor_explanations.E: describes numerous disorders affecting either T-lymphocyte maturation, survival, or function. Conditions such as severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome (SCIO) or Di George syndrome result in a near absence of T lymphocytes with recurrent viral and fungal infections. T lymphocytes also play a role in augmenting B-lymphocyte activation, so deficiency or dysfunction can impair humoral immunity. These patients present with severe and recurrent invasive infections early in life.

explanation.educational_objective: Selective lgA deficiency describes a decreased or absent concentration of circulating lgA, an immunoglobulin critical to mucosal immunity. Patients may be either asymptomatic or present with recurrent sinopulmonary infections, otitis media, and failure to thrive. Anaphylaxis following a blood transfusion as a result of preformed anti-lgA antibodies can also occur. lmmunoglobulin concentrations will demonstrate decreased or absent concentrations of lgA and normal or high concentrations of lgG and lgM. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
8. A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination . He is active and has been healthy except for an episode of otitis media 3 weeks ago
treated with amoxicillin . His parents emigrated from Vietnam . His diet consists mainly of fruits and vegetables ; he occasionally eats fish and chicken but no red
meat. Examination shows no abnormalities . Laboratory studies show :
Hemoglobin 10 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 64 µm 3
Leukocyte count 6100/mm 3
Platelet count 225 ,000/mm 3
Red cell distribution width 10% (N=13%-15%)
A blood smear is shown . Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's anemia?

question_stem: the most likely explanation for this patient's anemia?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This asymptomatic child with mild anemia, microcytosis, and low red cell distribution width (RDW), who is of Southeast Asian heritage most likely has either a- or ~-thalassemia minor. Thalassemia is characterized by the decreased synthesis of globin chains. Normal adult hemoglobin is known as HbA (a~2l and is made of two a-globin chains and two ~-globin chains. There are four a-globin alleles and two ~-globin alleles. Mutations in one or two a-globin alleles or one ~-globin allele causes thalassemia minor. Thalassemia trait is common in Southeast Asia and presents with mild microcytic anemia. Features include the presence of target cells on peripheral blood smear (pictured in the photomicrograph above), a low RDW (which indicates that most erythrocytes are of the same size with little variation), and persistence of microcytosis. Iron concentrations can be measured to rule out iron deficiency. Other cell lines including platelets and white blood cells should be within normal ranges. Hemoglobin electrophoresis can be used to distinguish between a- and ~-thalassemia minor. There is no treatment required for thalassemia minor as the resultant anemia is usually not severe. lncorrectAnswers:A, C, D, and E. Antibiotic-induced autoimmune hemolysis (Choice A) can occur after exposure to penicillins and cephalosporins, but the onset is typically acute and occurs within hours to days. While hemolysis can occur weeks later, it is less common. Additionally, patients would be expected to present with normocytic anemia and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Haptoglobin concentrations can be measured and will be decreased, while the reticulocyte count will typically be increased. Iron deficiency (Choice C) is a common cause of anemia in menstruating women, strict vegans or vegetarians, and those with chronic gastrointestinal bleeding or Celiac disease. It commonly presents with microcytosis, although often with a mean corpuscular volume (MCV) that is higher than what is seen in thalassemia, and an increased RDW indicating the release of premature erythrocytes, which are larger, from the bone marrow. The measurement of serum iron and ferritin are used to make the diagnosis. Transient postinfectious bone marrow suppression (Choice D) may occur following viral infections, but more commonly presents with leukopenia, which is not present in this case. In patients with sickle cell disease, infection with parvovirus B19 can cause a transient aplastic crisis and severe anemia. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.educational_objective: Thalassemia minor can occur as a result of mutations or deletions in one of the ~-globin alleles or in one or two of the a-globin alleles, leading to the impaired production of globin chains. Patients typically demonstrate a mild microcytic anemia with a low red cell distribution width and normal concentrations of leukocytes and platelets. Hemoglobin electrophoresis can be used to distinguish between these two entities. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Thalassemia minor can occur as a result of mutations or deletions in one of the ~-globin alleles or in one or two of the a-globin alleles, leading to the impaired production of globin chains. Patients

9. A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination . He has no history of serious illness . During the past 2 years , he has noticed brown urine whenever he has a cold . He has not had
dysuria or urinary urgency or incontinence . Examination shows no abnormalities . Laboratory studies show :
Serum
Urea nitrogen 15 mg/dl
Creatinine 0.9 mg/dl
C3 90 mg/dl (N=83-177)
Urine
Blood 4+
Protein 3+
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: lgA nephropathy (Berger disease) is a type of nephritic syndrome resulting in episodic gross hematuria, often following an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal tract infection. Nephritic syndromes typically present with acute kidney injury with associated hematuria, red blood cell casts, and hypertension. On urinalysis, there will be a significant quantity of red blood cells (RBCs), possible RBC casts, and sub-nephrotic range proteinuria. Serum complement concentrations, including C3, are typically within reference ranges. This differentiates lgA nephropathy from postinfectious glomerulonephritis, which results in decreased serum C3 complement. Additionally, anti-streptolysin O and anti-DNase titers will be negative in lgA nephropathy. lncorrectAnswers:A, B, D, and E. Hemolytic uremic syndrome {Choice A) is caused by Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (O157:H?) and is usually accompanied by bloody diarrhea. This is characterized by a classic triad of thrombocytopenia, acute kidney injury, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. Hemorrhagic cystitis {Choice B) refers to inflammation of the urinary bladder, which commonly is secondary to an acute bacterial urinary tract infection presenting with dysuria, urinary urgency, and frequency. A typical infectious cystitis presents with increased urinary white blood cells with detectable leukocyte esterase and nitrites on urinalysis, depending on the infectious organism. In hemorrhagic cystitis, red blood cells are also present on urinalysis. Nephrotic syndrome {Choice D) typically presents with excessive proteinuria (>3 g/day) hyperlipidemia, hypoalbuminemia, and peripheral edema. It does not cause hematuria. The most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children is minimal change disease. Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis {Choice E) is a nephritic syndrome presenting with urinary RBCs and RBC casts, which typically occurs between 2 and 6 weeks after infection with group A ~-hemolytic streptococci. Results of laboratory studies will show decreased serum C3 concentrations, and anti-streptolysin O and anti-DNase titers are positive.

Serum complement concentrations, including C3, are typically within reference ranges. r " , r-- r ,

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient with cystic fibrosis is likely presenting with findings of volume overload in cor pulmonale. Patients with cystic fibrosis may develop pulmonary hypertension as a result of hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction and fibrotic remodeling in chronically hypoventilated and inflamed pulmonary parenchyma leading to increased vascular resistance. If severe, this process can lead to cor pulmonale, which refers to isolated right heart failure secondary to chronic pulmonary pathology with increased pulmonary vascular resistance and right-sided heart pressures. Right heart failure typically presents with venous congestion, seen as jugular venous distention, peripheral edema, and hepatomegaly with or without ascites.

distractor_explanations.A: occurs secondary to many causes, the most common being alcoholic and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. Cirrhosis presents with ascites, anasarca, jaundice, increased transaminases, low albumin concentration, and impaired hepatic synthetic function. While right heart failure may cause cirrhosis, this patient only has some consistent findings. Inferior vena cava obstruction {
distractor_explanations.C: causes the obstruction of venous drainage from the lower regions of the body, often related to an underlying malignancy and associated mass effect, thrombosis from an indwelling catheter, or as a result of compression by a gravid uterus. This patient lacks a history suggestive of any likely cause of inferior vena cava obstruction. Lymphedema {
distractor_explanations.D: refers to swelling secondary to abnormal lymphatic drainage of a region, often secondary to surgery, radiation, or invasive parasitic disease. This patient lacks the appropriate history for these causes. Nephrotic syndrome {
distractor_explanations.E: results from many causes and typically presents with proteinuria, edema, hyperlipidemia, and a hypercoagulable state. Cystic fibrosis does not commonly cause nephrotic syndrome. Protein-losing enteropathy {
distractor_explanations.F: refers to any gastrointestinal pathology that results in the loss of protein, which may present with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and peripheral edema. Potential causes include r " , r-- r ,

explanation.educational_objective: Cor pulmonale refers to isolated right heart failure secondary to chronic pulmonary pathology with increased pulmonary vascular resistance and right-sided heart pressures. Patients with cystic fibrosis may develop pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale as a result of chronic alveolar hypoventilation with reactive pulmonary hypoxic vasoconstriction and vascular remodeling. r " , r-- r ,

12. An 18-year-old man has had nausea , fatigue , and periorbital swelling for 4 days ; the swelling is worse in the morning . He had tonsillitis 2 weeks ago that resolved after treatment with penicillin . His temperature is
37°C (98.6°F) , pulse is 92/min , respirations are 20/min , and blood pressure is 170/95 mm Hg. There is periorbital edema bilaterally and trace ankle edema . The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities .
Laboratory studies show :
Serum
Urea nitrogen 60 mg/dl
Creatinine 4 mg/dl
Urine
Protein 1+
WBC few
RBC many
RBC casts 1/hpf
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A Acute renal failure

question_stem:
the most likely diagnosis?
A Acute renal failure

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient presents with acute renal failure following a tonsillar infection, consistent with a diagnosis of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), a nephritic syndrome. PSGN typically occurs between 2 and 4 weeks following an acute infection with Streptococcus pyogenes (group A) (typically impetigo, streptococcal pharyngitis, or tonsillitis). Appropriate treatment of the streptococcal infection with antibiotics does not reduce the likelihood of subsequently developing PSGN. PSGN is caused by a type Ill hypersensitivity reaction with the kidney deposition of immune complexes and complement. Patients typically present with dark colored urine, hypertension, and peripheral and periorbital edema. Urinalysis typically shows red blood cell casts. The diagnosis is confirmed with kidney biopsy, which shows enlarged glomeruli on light microscopy, bumpy irregularity of the glomerular basement membrane on immunofluorescence, and subepithelial immune complex deposits on electron microscopy. Treatment is supportive and includes diuretics and antihypertensive agents.

distractor_explanations.B: may occur in severe cases of myocarditis or rheumatic heart disease. Heart failure would not cause hematuria and red blood cell casts, which is more suggestive of a nephritic syndrome. Cirrhosis of the liver (
distractor_explanations.C: occurs secondary to many causes, the most common being alcoholic and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. Cirrhosis presents with ascites, anasarca, jaundice, increased transaminases, decreased albumin, and impaired hepatic synthetic function. It does not occur following streptococcal infections and does not usually present with hypertension or hematuria. Inferior vena cava obstruction (
distractor_explanations.D: prevents venous drainage from the inferior regions of the body, often related to an underlying malignancy and associated mass effect, thrombosis from an indwelling catheter, or as a result of compression by a gravid uterus. This patient lacks a history suggestive of any likely cause of inferior vena cava obstruction. Nephrotic syndrome (
distractor_explanations.E: results from many causes and typically presents with proteinuria, edema, hyperlipidemia, and a hypercoagulable state. PSGN is a primarily nephritic process and usually results in mild, sub-nephrotic range proteinuria.

explanation.educational_objective: Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis can cause acute renal failure following an acute infection with Streptococcus pyogenes (group A) (typically impetigo, streptococcal pharyngitis, tonsillitis). Patients present with dark-colored urine, hypertension, and peripheral and periorbital edema; urinalysis shows red blood casts. r " , r-- r ,

13. A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of vaginal bleeding for 12 hours . She has a 3-month history of a purulent vaginal discharge . Breast and pubic hair development is Tanner stage 1. Examination
shows a purulent bloody discharge on her underwear . Which of the following is the most likely cause?

question_stem: the most likely cause?

distractor_explanations.A: can occur with craniopharyngiomas, gliomas, or other central nervous system tumors. It is rare and would present with signs of precocious puberty including breast and pubic hair development, growth acceleration, and voice changes. Isolated menarche (
distractor_explanations.B: describes vaginal bleeding in a prepubertal child in which no secondary causes have been identified, such as precocious puberty, infection, foreign bodies, trauma, or tumors. In a patient with purulent and bloody vaginal discharge, the presence of a foreign body is more likely. Vulvovaginitis (
distractor_explanations.C: involves the overgrowth of normal vaginal Candida flora, bacterial vaginosis, or Trichomonas vaginitis. Candida as a cause of vulvovaginitis can be distinguished from other causes by abnormal, often white, vaginal discharge with normal vaginal pH, negative KOH testing, and the absence of motile trichomonads on wet mount preparation. Risk factors for Candida vulvovaginitis include the use of medications, especially antibiotics, or an immunocompromised state. It would be unlikely in this child with none of these risk factors. Vaginal tumors (
distractor_explanations.E: can include squamous cell carcinoma, melanoma, adenocarcinoma, and sarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is a rare, aggressive malignancy formed by striated muscle cells. It is found in children and can present as a genitourinary mass with hematuria, urinary tract obstruction, or a protruding vaginal mass.

explanation.educational_objective: Vaginal foreign bodies can present in prepubertal children with genital discomfort, vulvar erythema, vaginal discharge, or vaginal bleeding. While sexual abuse should be considered, vaginal a foreign bodies are more common as a result of child's curiosity and exploratory genital play. r " , r-- r ,

14. A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 10 minutes after he was found coughing and choking near an open can of peanuts . His parents attempted a Heimlich
maneuver , but his condition did not improve . On arrival , he is agitated and unable to speak because of shortness of breath . His pulse is 150/min , respirations are 35/min , and blood
pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. Examination shows intercostal and suprasternal retractions . There are wheezes and poor air movement on the right. An expiratory x-ray of the chest is
shown . Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?

question_stem: the most likely explanation for these findings?

choices.text: Complete obstruction and collapse of the left lung
Partial obstruction of the right main stem bronchus

distractor_explanations.A: would be suggested if there were increased interstitial markings on the left side compared to the right during an inspiratory chest x-ray. Aspiration pneumonia may be caused by infection from oropharyngeal microbes. L R Complete obstruction and collapse of the left lung (

of sausage shortly before he became ill. Earlier today, the patient was given the task of cleaning out the garage . On arrival , the patient is alert and is not in respiratory distress . His pulse is 136/min , respirations are 20/min , and
blood pressure is 104/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 73% that increases to 80% when 15 L/min of oxygen is administered via face mask . Examination shows profound central cyanosis .
The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities . His methemoglobin is 40 .5% of his total hemoglobin . Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows :

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Methemoglobinemia occurs when an abnormal fraction of heme iron in the blood exists in the ferric (Fe 3 form (methemoglobin). Methemoglobin cannot effectively bind oxygen, which impairs tissue oxygen delivery. •) Most cases of methemoglobinemia are acquired, typically via exposure to an oxidant stressor such as an anesthetic (eg, benzocaine), nitrate, or dapsone. Symptoms include shortness of breath, fatigue, lethargy, lightheadedness, and in severe cases, arrhythmia, seizure, and multisystem organ failure. Vital signs typically show reduced oxygen saturation, and examination may disclose cyanosis. Characteristically, blood appears darkened on gross visualization, although hemoglobin concentration and erythrocyte morphology are normal. Treatment includes supplemental oxygen plus the intravenous administration of methylene blue, a reducing agent that donates electrons to heme. The reduction of heme iron to the ferrous (Fe 2 form restores the ability of hemoglobin to bind, carry, and deliver oxygen to tissues. •) lncorrectAnswers:A, B, D, E, and F. Administration of atropine (Choice A) would be indicated in cases of symptomatic bradycardia or organophosphate poisoning. This patient's pulse is tachycardic and atropine administration would be inappropriate. Administration of deferoxamine (Choice B) is indicated in the treatment of hemochromatosis or iron toxicity. It is a therapy that binds free iron in the serum and promotes elimination in the urine. Administration of naloxone (Choice D) is indicated in cases of opioid overdose. Opioid overdoses are characterized by respiratory depression presenting as a decreased respiratory rate, apnea, and hypoxia. This patient's hypoxia is caused by methemoglobinemia, not respiratory depression. Administration of pyridostigmine (Choice E) is used in the treatment of myasthenia gravis. It is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that increases the concentration of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy (Choice F) can be helpful in the treatment of decompression sickness and carbon monoxide poisoning.

vignette.presentation:
16. A 10-day-old male newborn is admitted to the hospital for treatment of indirect hyperbilirubinemia due to isoimmune hemolysis . He is placed in a room with a 2-month-old female infant with dehydration secondary to rotavirus
gastroenteritis . Two days later, he develops vomiting and diarrhea , and a stool specimen is positive for rotavirus antigen . This nosocomial infection is most likely caused by failure of caregivers to do which of the following?

question_stem: most likely caused by failure of caregivers to do which of the following?

choices.text: Dispose of diapers and other waste items properly
Place the patients in a reverse airflow room

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Observation of proper hand-washing techniques is the most effective strategy to limit the spread of nosocomial enteric viral pathogens. Viral shedding in the stool can occur prior to the development of symptoms and potentially allow asymptomatic patients to become vectors for disease. Additionally, viral shedding in the stool persists until after the resolution of symptoms. Alcohol-based hand sanitizers are not as efficacious at removing enteric viruses from the hands or other commonly touched surfaces, although cleaning agents that utilize bleach are effective. It is likely that the 10-day-old newborn acquired rotavirus infection after caregivers came in contact with a surface contaminated by feces from the 2-month-old infant and then touched the younger child without washing their hands properly. Spread of enteric viruses can be reduced by simply by performing routine hand washing, which typically involves rubbing the hands together with soap for at least twenty seconds. Individuals often neglect to scrub the entire surface of the hand despite an adequate duration of hand washing.

distractor_explanations.A: is also important, as rotavirus is shed in the stool, but adherence to these measures tends to be higher amongst caregivers than the simple observance of hand washing. It is unlikely that the patient acquired infection directly through contact with the other patient's diapers; caregivers more likely touched other contaminated surfaces. Observing gown and glove precautions (
distractor_explanations.B: is an important part of preventing the spread of certain bacteria and viruses, and contact precautions are often instituted in instances of viral gastroenteritis. However, proper hand washing should always occur before and after donning and doffing gown and gloves. Placing the patient in a reverse airflow room (
distractor_explanations.D: would have little effect on the transmission of rotavirus as this pathogen is not transmitted by aerosolized particles. Negative pressure rooms are more commonly reserved for airborne pathogens such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis and measles, among others. Restricting visitors to the room (
distractor_explanations.E: decreases the number of individuals who can potentially act as vectors to transfer rotavirus between the patients, but observing proper hand washing is more likely to reduce the spread of infection regardless of the number of visitors.

explanation.educational_objective: Proper hand-washing technique includes rubbing the hands together with soap for at least twenty seconds before rinsing. It is common for individuals to neglect to scrub the entire surface of the hands. Hand washing is more efficacious in preventing the spread of enteric pathogens than any other preventive measure and should be observed judiciously. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Proper hand-washing technique includes rubbing the hands together with soap for at least twenty seconds before rinsing. It is common for individuals to neglect to scrub the entire surface of the hands

The liver edge is palpated 1 cm below the right costal margin ; the spleen tip is palpated 7 cm below the left costal margin . Laboratory studies show :
