distractor_explanations.A: causes decreased serum cortisol and presents with fatigue, hypotension, hypoglycemia, and abdominal pain. In children, it is commonly caused by congenital adrenal hyperplasia, which leads to varying concentrations of mineralocorticoids, glucocorticoids, and androgens depending on the enzyme affected. In general, it presents with ambiguous genitalia or precocious puberty and can present with salt wasting in infancy. This patient has a normal genital examination, making this less likely. Hypermagnesemia (
distractor_explanations.B: in infants can be caused by magnesium sulfate administration in the mother in preeclampsia or eclampsia. It causes hypotonia and respiratory depression in the newborn but does not cause jitteriness. Hypocalcemia (

It is commonly associated with DiGeorge syndrome, which causes parathyroid hypoplasia, and resultant severe hypocalcemia. However, DiGeorge syndrome is associated with craniofacial abnormalities that this patient does not exhibit. Hypothyroidism (
distractor_explanations.E: presents in the first few months of life with feeding difficulties, lethargy, constipation, myxedema, macroglossia, large fontanelles, hypotonia, and hypothermia. It is not generally apparent at birth.

explanation.educational_objective: Maternal diabetes mellitus exposes a fetus to increased concentrations of blood glucose, in response to which the fetus increases production of insulin and decreases gluconeogenesis. Following birth, this can lead to postnatal hypoglycemia as the newborn is no longer exposed to increased concentrations of blood glucose in the maternal circulation. This presents with tremors, diaphoresis, irritability, lethargy, and seizures. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
39. Twelve hours after undergoing circumcision , a 3-day-old boy has persistent bleeding at his circumcision site. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation to a 23-year-old primigravid woman following an uncomplicated pregnancy and
delivery. He was given an intramuscular injection of vitamin K immediately after delivery. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 55/min , and blood pressure is 60/40 mm Hg. Examination shows a
prominent right parietal cephalohematoma . There is an ecchymosis at the vitamin K injection site and continuous oozing of blood at the circumcision site. Laboratory studies show:
Hematocrit 53%
Leukocyte count 10,500/mm 3
Segmented neutrophils 50%
Basophils 4%
Lymphocytes 40%
Monocytes 6%
Platelet count 350,000/mm 3
Prothrombin time 12 sec {INR=1.05)
Partial thromboplastin time 90 sec
Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
A Factor VIII deficiency

question_stem:
the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
A Factor VIII deficiency

choices.text: Respiratory distress syndrome of the newborn
Determine the exact amount and type of alcohol ingested
Folliculitis I) Mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome (Kawasaki disease)

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Factor VIII deficiency resulting in hemophilia A is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with uncontrolled bleeding from his circumcision site, large right cephalohematoma, an abnormally prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT), normal prothrombin time (PT), and normal platelet count. Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive condition and is therefore more commonly seen in males, while most females are silent carriers. It is caused by an absence or deficiency of factor VIII, which is a component of the intrinsic clotting cascade. Factor VIII is required as a cofactor for the activation of factor X to factor Xa, which in turn converts prothrombin to thrombin to complete the process of clot formation. The PTT measures the activity of the intrinsic pathway and will be prolonged in cases of hemophilia A, while the PT measures the activity of factor VII (extrinsic pathway), which is normal in patients with this disease.

distractor_explanations.B: can be inherited or acquired and can also result in prolonged bleeding, but the PTT is usually normal, while bleeding time would be increased. Examples of inherited platelet disorders include Glanzmann thrombasthenia, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, and platelet granule disorders. Sepsis {
distractor_explanations.C: is an unlikely diagnosis in this patient without fever or signs of infection. Common infections that cause sepsis in the newborn period include meningitis and pneumonia. Vitamin K deficiency {
distractor_explanations.D: is unlikely because this child was given a dose of vitamin K, which is adequate to correct any deficiency. Additionally, this would present with a prolonged PT. von Willebrand factor deficiency {
distractor_explanations.E: can present with bleeding and is caused by quantitative or qualitative abnormality of von Willebrand factor (vW
distractor_explanations.F: , which binds platelets and subendothelial collagen in primary hemostasis. Impaired platelet adherence leads to prolonged bleeding time. It can present with epistaxis, gingival bleeding, petechiae, easy bruising, and menorrhagia.

explanation.educational_objective: Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disease resulting in deficiency or absence of factor VIII. It presents with prolonged bleeding following tissue injury. Laboratory studies will show a prolonged PTT but normal PT and normal platelet count. Treatment is with recombinant factor VIII. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disease resulting in deficiency or absence of factor VIII. It presents with prolonged bleeding following tissue injury. Laboratory studies will show a prolonged P

vignette.presentation:
50. A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician because his parents are concerned that he has had several episodes of tripping and incoordination over the past 10 months . He has high-arched feet and hammer toes . His father
also has high-arched feet and a history of distal extremity weakness . His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus and severe diabetic neuropathy . Examination of the patient shows mild weakness of the hand musculature and
weakness and wasting of the anterior tibial and intrinsic foot muscles . Deep tendon reflexes are absent at the ankles and decreased elsewhere . Sensation to vibration and proprioception are mildly decreased over the distal
lower extremities . Motor nerve conduction velocities are markedly decreased with prolonged distal motor latencies in the extremities . Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's weakness?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's weakness?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT) is a heritable disease of peripheral neuropathy. As a result of primarily autosomal dominant mutations in genes expressed in Schwann cells, the myelinating cells of the peripheral nervous system, peripheral sensory and motor nerves become progressively demyelinated. Patients demonstrate motor weakness and decreased sensation to vibration and proprioception most prominent in the distal lower extremities. Physical examination findings include hyporeflexia or areflexia, along with clumsy walking and consequent musculoskeletal deformities such as pes cavus (high arch of the foot) and hammer toes (toes with an abnormal upward bend of the middle joint). Later in the disease course, atrophy of the lower extremity muscles and intrinsic hand muscle weakness and atrophy may occur. Diagnosis occurs via nerve conduction studies, which may show decreased conduction velocities and prolonged distal motor latencies consistent with demyelinating disease (some disease subtypes show decreased amplitudes suggestive of axonal loss). Treatment is supportive and includes physical therapy.

distractor_explanations.B: is an acquired, immune-mediated disease of the peripheral nerve roots that leads to symmetric proximal and distal motor weakness and decreased sensation to vibration and proprioception. The course may be relapsing-remitting or progressive. In this patient with a family history suggestive of peripheral neuropathy, CMT is more likely. Diabetic neuropathy (
distractor_explanations.C: is an acquired, symmetric polyneuropathy that predominantly affects the sensory nerves of the distal lower and upper extremities. Motor weakness typically occurs only in severe cases, after years of hyperglycemia. Duchenne muscular dystrophy (
distractor_explanations.D: , caused by an inherited mutation in the dystrophin gene, typically presents at age 2 to 3 years with progressive muscle weakness affecting the proximal more than the distal muscles. Cardiac conduction abnormalities are also common. Sensory neuropathy would be atypical. Facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (
distractor_explanations.E: an inherited muscular dystrophy resulting in slowly progressive, asymmetric muscle weakness in the facial, scapular, upper arm, lower leg, and abdominal muscles. Sensory neuropathy would be atypical.

explanation.educational_objective: In Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, an autosomal dominant mutation expressed in Schwann cells leads to symmetric motor and sensory polyneuropathy that begins in the distal lower extremities and may progress to the upper extremities. Muscle weakness typically results in hyporeflexia and progresses to muscle atrophy. Sensation to vibration and proprioception is frequently affected. Patients demonstrate a clumsy gait and consequent skeletal deformities such as pes cavus and hammer toes. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: In Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, an autosomal dominant mutation expressed in Schwann cells leads to symmetric motor and sensory polyneuropathy that begins in the distal lower extremities and may progre

vignette.presentation:
1. A 20-year-old woman , gravida 1, para 0, at 36 weeks' gestation delivers a stillborn infant. She had no prenatal care , and the prenatal course was complicated by maternal cocaine and alcohol use. She also was seen in the
emergency department at 20 weeks' gestation after being assaulted by her boyfriend . Examination at the time showed scalp and forearm lacerations and bruising of the abdomen and face . She took phenytoin during the
pregnancy for a seizure disorder ; she had no seizures during the pregnancy . An autopsy of the fetus shows multiple fractures of thin ribs and multiple fractures of the rather broad and ribbon-shaped tubular bones . Examination of
the fetus shows blue sclerae , soft calvaria , a small chest , and bent short extremities . Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this condition?

question_stem: the most likely underlying cause of this condition?

choices.text: Intrauterine trauma resulting from abuse to the mother

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This infant likely died from complications of osteogenesis imperfecta, which results from mutations or posttranslational defects in collagen, type I. Given the presence of collagen, type I, in bone, skin, and connective tissues, pathology results from connective tissue defects ranging in severity from postpubertal fractures to fatal fractures in utero. The presentation of this fetus likely reflects fragile long bones along with decreased calvarial ossification and thin sclerae (leading to visualization of the choroidal veins). Patients may also present with short stature, scoliosis, basilar skull deformities (leading to nerve compression), hearing loss (likely related to abnormal bone formation in the ossicles and cochlea), opalescent and fragile teeth, and easy bruising (caused by collagen, type I, defects in blood vessel walls). Treatment is primarily supportive, involving possible bisphosphonates along with monitoring for complications, physical therapy, and genetic counseling.

distractor_explanations.B: include intellectual disability, developmental delay, and physical malformations such as microcephaly, facial dysmorphia, limb deformities, and congenital heart disease. Patients with fetal alcohol syndrome may demonstrate abnormal bone development (eg, cervical spine fusion) and delayed bone growth. However, osseous fragility would be atypical. Intrauterine trauma resulting from abuse to the mother (
distractor_explanations.C: may lead to increased fetal cortisol production and stress physiology. However, in the absence of a blunt or penetrating injury to the mother, mechanical trauma to the fetus would be unlikely. Placental insufficiency from cocaine use (
distractor_explanations.D: can lead to preterm birth, intrauterine growth restriction, low birth weight, and placental abruption. However, osseous fragility would be atypical. Teratogenicity of phenytoin (
distractor_explanations.E: commonly causes orofacial clefts, cardiac malformations, and genitourinary defects. In adults, phenytoin may cause osteomalacia as a result of changes in calcium metabolism. However, maternal phenytoin use is unlikely to result in osseous fragility in infants.

explanation.educational_objective: In osteogenesis imperfecta, abnormalities of collagen, type I, lead to connective tissue defects and consequent bone fractures, scoliosis, short stature, skull deformities, blue sclera, fragile teeth, hearing loss, and easy bruising. Severe cases lead to death in utero. r , " , F'
explanation.concept: In osteogenesis imperfecta, abnormalities of collagen, type I, lead to connective tissue defects and consequent bone fractures, scoliosis, short stature, skull deformities, blue sclera, fragile teeth,

vignette.presentation:
2. A previously healthy 1-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-month history of increasing weakness and difficulty feeding . He is alert . Examination shows tongue fasciculations and profound hypotonia . Deep
tendon reflexes are absent. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

distractor_explanations.A: is an acute disease of the neuromuscular junction caused by the exposure to the C/ostridium botulinum toxin (eg, in raw honey). Over the course of hours to days, patients develop symmetric hypotonia and hyporeflexia that begins with the cranial nerves and descends to the lower extremities in a presentation that may mimic SMA. However, this patient's weakness developed over the course of months rather than hours to days. Guillain-Barre syndrome (
distractor_explanations.B: results from the autoimmune attack of the spinal nerve roots and typically presents with acute-onset, symmetric, ascending muscle weakness with hyporeflexia. This patient's weakness instead progressed over months. Many patients also demonstrate autonomic dysfunction and/or sensory symptoms, which would be atypical in SMA. Myasthenia gravis (
distractor_explanations.C: is an autoimmune disorder of neuromuscular transmission that may result in focal or generalized muscle weakness and fatigability. Myasthenia gravis demonstrates a bimodal age of onset in both young adults (teens to 20s) and older adults (50s to 60s). Myasthenia gravis in an infant would be atypical. Transverse myelitis (
distractor_explanations.E: is an acquired condition in which inflammation (eg, from an infection or autoimmune disease) affects one section of the spinal cord bilaterally, leading to acute motor, sensory, or autonomic dysfunction. This patient instead experienced the insidious onset of motor dysfunction only.

explanation.educational_objective: In spinal muscular atrophy, the bilateral lower brainstem motor nuclei and anterior horns degenerate, leading to progressive, symmetric muscular weakness and a lower motor neuron-pattern of dysfunction (eg, decreased tone, hyporeflexia, fasciculations, early-onset atrophy). Deficits typically progress during the course of months, which differentiates spinal muscular atrophy from the acute descending motor weakness of botulism. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: In spinal muscular atrophy, the bilateral lower brainstem motor nuclei and anterior horns degenerate, leading to progressive, symmetric muscular weakness and a lower motor neuron-pattern of dysfunctio

vignette.presentation:
3. An asymptomatic 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination . He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications . His parents both have essential hypertension and hyperlipidemia . He has
an active lifestyle and plays several sports . He consumes a wide variety of foods , including meat , fruit , and vegetables , and drinks two to three glasses each of whole milk and fruit juice daily. He is currently at the 75th percentile
for height and above the 97th percentile for weight and BMI. Vital signs are within normal limits . The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current
weight?

question_stem:
the most likely cause of this patient's current
weight?

choices.text: Inadequate intake of fruits and vegetables

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: In children, overweight is defined as a BMI at or above the 85th percentile and below the 95th percentile for age and gender, while obesity is defined as a BMI at or above the 95th percentile. This obese child consumes a balanced diet but one that most likely contains excessive total calories. Common causes of childhood obesity include consuming a diet rich in unhealthy, calorie-rich foods, and a lack of sufficient exercise. Children from socioeconomically disadvantaged communities may face significant difficulties in obtaining healthy food and sufficient opportunity for exercise. Children with obesity are more likely to develop comorbidities such as hypertension and diabetes mellitus.

distractor_explanations.A: and excessive intake of fat (
distractor_explanations.B: are both correct but insufficient to explain this child's obesity. This child consumes a balanced diet as well as several glasses of both milk and fruit juice daily and is likely consuming an excess of both carbohydrates and fat, as well as protein. Inadequate intake of fruits and vegetables (
distractor_explanations.D: may lead to obesity indirectly by causing a child to consume an unhealthy diet that favors fatty or salty foods instead. This child does not have a history of consuming inadequate fruits or vegetables. Inadequate physical activity (
distractor_explanations.E: is a common cause of obesity in children. This child has an active lifestyle and his diet is a more likely cause of his obesity.

explanation.educational_objective: In children, overweight is defined as a BMI at or above the 85th percentile and below the 95th percentile for age and gender, while obesity is defined as a BMI at or above the 95th percentile. Common causes of childhood obesity include consuming an excessive amount of total calories, a diet rich in unhealthy, calorie-rich foods, and a lack of sufficient exercise. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
4. A 10-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 5-day history of a rash over the cheeks and diaper area that she constantly rubs . Her mother says that for the past 24 hours , she has been unwilling to stand . She is
afebrile and otherwise healthy. Her mother and 6-year-old brother have asthma . Examination shows erythematous lichenified papules and plaques , and excoriations on the diaper area . She has red lichenified plaques on the
cheek and chin . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Atopic dermatitis, or eczema, is a chronic pruritic inflammatory skin disease common in children that is suggested by pruritus and recurrent eczematous rashes. The rash is initially characterized by erythematous papules and vesicles with exudates and crusting and, with chronic scratching, becomes dry, scaly, and excoriated in a process called lichenification. Flexural dermatitis (eg, in the antecubital fossae) is a common pattern in children and adults with atopic dermatitis, but babies demonstrate a unique pattern, which primarily involves the bilateral cheeks and diaper area, as these areas are both frequently moist and subject to irritation. Treatment of atopic dermatitis begins with gentle skin care: minimizing long baths in warm water which causes drying of the skin, avoiding products with fragrance, and use of bland moisturizers such as petroleum jelly daily. In the case of an infant, keeping the cheeks dry and frequent diaper changes are also important. Flares of eczema are treated with mild- to moderate-potency topical corticosteroids, such as triamcinolone. In children, a moderate-potency topical corticosteroid should not be used consistently for over 2 to 3 weeks because of the potential of systemic absorption, particularly in the diaper area.

distractor_explanations.B: can affect mucous membranes or skin. Oral candidiasis demonstrates thick, white plaques on the tongue or buccal mucosa, which can be scraped off. Cutaneous candidiasis demonstrates red, macerated thin plaques with satellite papules. Candidiasis is a common cause of diaper rash, but in this case, given the additional findings on the face, atopic dermatitis is more likely. Food allergy (
distractor_explanations.C: rarely contributes to atopic dermatitis. Patients with diaper dermatitis caused or worsened by food allergy will also demonstrate gastrointestinal symptoms including diarrhea, which is absent in this case. There is no role for specific food avoidance diets in the treatment of pediatric atopic dermatitis. Tinea corporis (
distractor_explanations.D: is caused by a superficial dermatophyte infection of the skin, most often Trichophyton tonsurans. The classic appearance is a round, annular patch with a scaly border. Potassium hydroxide preparation will disclose hyphae. Toxic epidermal necrolysis (
distractor_explanations.E: is a life-threatening adverse cutaneous drug reaction. Features such as skin pain, sloughing, or mucosal involvement are concerning for toxic epidermal necrolysis. This patient's lichenified papules and plaques are more consistent with atopic dermatitis.

explanation.educational_objective: Atopic dermatitis is a chronic pruritic inflammatory skin disease common in children that is suggested by pruritus and recurrent eczematous rashes. In infants, atopic dermatitis primarily involves the bilateral cheeks and diaper area, as these areas are both frequently moist and subject to irritation. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Atopic dermatitis is a chronic pruritic inflammatory skin disease common in children that is suggested by pruritus and recurrent eczematous rashes. In infants, atopic dermatitis primarily involves the

vignette.presentation:
5. An otherwise healthy 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of the growth of pubic hair over the past 2 years . He is 157 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 50 kg (110 lb). He appears muscular . Pubic hair development is
Tanner stage 5. Examination shows a mature penis . Testicular volume is normal for age . Which of the following is the most likely site of excessive hormonal production?

question_stem: the most likely site of excessive hormonal production?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Precocious puberty is defined as the onset of pubertal development and secondary sexual characteristics prior to 8 years of age in girls and 9 years of age in boys. Precocious puberty can be central, which is caused by activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. This early activation can be idiopathic or caused by central nervous system abnormalities, such as a brain tumor. Precocious puberty can also be peripheral, which is caused by the release of excess sex hormones from the gonads or adrenal glands, or potentially the ectopic production of human chorionic gonadotropin from a germ-cell tumor. Initial evaluation involves the measurement of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), luteinizing hormone {LH), and estradiol or testosterone, which allows the provider to differentiate between central and peripheral causes of precocious puberty. Central precocious puberty is further evaluated with brain imaging, whereas peripheral precocious puberty is further evaluated with ultrasonography of the testes, ovaries, or adrenal glands. Treatment is dependent on the underlying pathology. As testicular size is based on the production of FSH, this patient more likely has a peripheral cause of precocious puberty with hyperandrogenism leading to inhibition of the release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), FSH, and LH. Adrenal causes of precocious puberty include congenital adrenal hyperplasia and androgen-secreting tumors. Treatment for precocious puberty is dependent on the underlying pathology.

distractor_explanations.B: could cause central precocious puberty, which would present with increased concentrations of GnRH, FSH, and LH. Central precocious puberty can be idiopathic or caused by central nervous system lesions, such as an astrocytoma. However, increased concentrations of FSH in this patient would lead to a mature testicular size, rather than a testicular size congruent with the patient's age. The liver {
distractor_explanations.C: does not typically produce hormones. It does play a role in the metabolism of estrogen, thus a patient with liver cirrhosis can develop signs of hyperestrogenism, such as gynecomastia, menstrual irregularities, spider angiomata, and palmar erythema. However, liver failure is not a common cause of precocious puberty in children. Excess hormone production from the pituitary gland {
distractor_explanations.D: could lead to central precocious puberty with increased concentrations of FSH and LH. This can occur in the setting of a gonadotropin-secreting tumor, although these are exceedingly rare in children. As this patient has age-appropriate testicular size, peripheral precocious puberty is more likely. Excess hormone production from the testes {
distractor_explanations.E: can present with the peripheral precocious puberty seen in this patient. However, the most common cause of a testicular pathology leading to precocious puberty in young boys is a Leydig cell tumor, which would be expected to present with asymmetric enlargement of the testes, not seen in this patient.

explanation.educational_objective: Precocious puberty is the development of secondary sexual characteristics before age 8 years in girls and age 9 years in boys. It can be central, with increased FSH and LH concentrations, or peripheral, with decreased FSH and LH concentrations. Peripheral precocious puberty can be caused by abnormalities in the gonads or adrenal glands. In young boys, adrenal pathology typically causes precocious puberty with age-appropriate testicular size given the androgen-induced feedback inhibition of FSH and LH. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Precocious puberty is the development of secondary sexual characteristics before age 8 years in girls and age 9 years in boys. It can be central, with increased FSH and LH concentrations, or periphera

vignette.presentation:
6. A 3-week-old boy is brought to the physician 4 hours after the onset of vomiting watery, green material. His mother says that he has been drawing up his legs as if in pain while vomiting . He appears uncomfortable . He is
afebrile . The abdomen is tender but not distended. An abdominal x-ray shows dilated loops of small bowel and air-fluid levels . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Foreign body ingestion I) Pyloric stenosis

distractor_explanations.A: typically presents with right lower quadrant abdominal pain that is often periumbilical at onset, along with nausea, anorexia, fever, leukocytosis, and tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant on examination. It does not cause bowel obstruction or bilious vomiting. Congenital megacolon (Hirschsprung disease) {
distractor_explanations.B: , also known as intestinal aganglionosis, is caused by the congenital absence of the distal portion of the myenteric plexus. This often leads to an inability to pass meconium within the first few days of life and may result in a large bowel obstruction. An explosive expulsion of feces on rectal examination is a classic clinical finding. Duodenal atresia {
distractor_explanations.C: is caused by failure of recanalization of the duodenal lumen. Duodenal atresia presents with vomiting and abdominal distension, as well as gaseous dilation of the stomach and duodenum on an abdominal x-ray. Foreign body ingestion {
distractor_explanations.D: may cause intestinal obstruction and bilious vomiting. However, it is more common in older infants and toddlers who tend to put items in their mouths, not 3-week-old newborns. In an infant, gastroesophageal reflux disease {
distractor_explanations.E: presents with frequent regurgitation without excessive irritability. Bilious vomiting is a warning sign of a structural cause of vomiting. Hepatitis {
distractor_explanations.F: can be caused by viral infections, autoimmune diseases, or medications. Hyperbilirubinemia with jaundice or icterus is often present. It is not a cause of small bowel obstruction or bilious vomiting. lntussusception {
distractor_explanations.G: occurs when an intestinal lead point causes the small or large intestine to telescope on itself. It presents with episodic, crampy abdominal pain accompanied by crying, vomiting, and bloody, mucoid stool. Pancreatitis {
distractor_explanations.H: presents with epigastric abdominal pain that radiates to the back, along with nausea and emesis. Acute pancreatitis can be complicated by necrosis, hemorrhage, abscess, or the formation of pseudocysts, but generally not a small bowel obstruction. Pyloric stenosis {
distractor_explanations.I: is caused by hypertrophy of the pyloric sphincter, leading to gastric outlet obstruction and vomiting. It commonly presents with non bloody, nonbilious emesis after feedings, and begins around 3 to 6 weeks of age.

explanation.educational_objective: Congenital malrotation of the intestines predisposes to midgut volvulus, which presents with signs of small bowel obstruction including bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. X-ray findings of small bowel obstruction include dilated loops of bowel with air-fluid levels. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Congenital malrotation of the intestines predisposes to midgut volvulus, which presents with signs of small bowel obstruction including bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. X-ray findings of sma

7. A previously healthy 6-month-old boy is admitted to the hospital because of a 1-day history of fever, lethargy, and vomiting . His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 160/min, and respirations are 34/min . Examination shows
nuchal rigidity and a bulging anterior fontanel. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities . Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 12.2 g/dL
Leukocyte count 17,300/mm 3

Serum

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's serum sodium concentration?

question_stem: the most likely explanation for this patient's serum sodium concentration?

choices.text: Increased loss of chloride in the kidneys
Increased loss of chloride in the kidneys

distractor_explanations.A: can occur with psychogenic polydipsia, resulting in dilute urine and hyponatremia. It would be unlikely in this patient presenting with meningitis, and the cause of hyponatremia is more likely a result of SIADH. Factitious hyponatremia due to hyperglycemia (
distractor_explanations.B: can occur in patients with severe hyperglycemia. This patient's glucose is 150 mg/dL, which would not be enough to cause hyponatremia on laboratory evaluation. Severe hyperglycemia can lead to the osmotic shift of water from the intracellular to extracellular space, leading to dilutional hyponatremia in the serum. Increased loss of chloride in the kidneys (
distractor_explanations.C: would not explain this patient's hyponatremia. Chloride is typically reabsorbed with sodium in the nephron. The patient's hyponatremia is not caused by abnormalities of sodium or chloride reabsorption or excretion, but rather, increased free water reabsorption as a result of SIADH. The patient's chloride concentration is normal. Insufficient intake of sodium chloride (
distractor_explanations.E: would not itself cause hyponatremia as a result of the kidney's ability to reabsorb sodium and water to maintain a homeostatic serum osmolarity. SIADH impairs this ability by causing unregulated free water reabsorption. r " , r-- r ,

explanation.educational_objective: SIADH can occur as an adverse effect of medications (eg, cyclophosphamide), a paraneoplastic process, or secondary to a central nervous system disorder (eg, stroke, hemorrhage, infection, trauma, or tumor). r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
8. A 2-month -old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination . Pregnancy was uncomplicated . He was born at term following forceps delivery for fetal heart rate decelerations . Apgar scores were 4 and 8 at 1 and 5
minutes , respectively . He is at the 50th percentile for length and 75th percentile for weight. He keeps his head turned to the right and cries when it is moved toward the left. Examination shows flattening of the right posterior part
of the skull. A 1.5-cm mass is palpated in the left side of the neck . Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

question_stem: the most likely cause of these findings?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient likely experienced an injury of the sternomastoid (also known as sternocleidomastoid, or SCM) muscle as a result of birth trauma, leading to congenital torticollis. Torticollis refers to an abnormal contraction of the neck muscles that results in the head tilting to one side. Congenital torticollis typically presents beginning at 2 to 4 weeks of age with a preferred head position, decreased cervical range of motion, and a mass of the SCM. Hypothesized causes include birth trauma (eg, forceps delivery) or intrauterine malposition of the head, which may lead to SCM injury and consequent fibrosis and contracture of the SCM. The fibrosis may present as a mass of the SCM on physical examination. Birth trauma or intrauterine head malposition may also lead to plagiocephaly (flattening of the head). The diagnosis of congenital torticollis is clinical. Treatment requires physical therapy interventions to stretch the SCM, which leads to the resolution of torticollis in most infants.

distractor_explanations.A: refers to a rare condition of incomplete vertebral ossification in the cervical spine and may present with cervical scoliosis, neck pain, and torticollis. This condition is not associated with birth trauma and would not demonstrate plagiocephaly or a mass of the SCM. Craniosynostosis (
distractor_explanations.B: refers to the premature ossification (closure) of some cranial bone sutures, resulting in asymmetric skull growth in infants. Torticollis and a mass of the SCM would be atypical. Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (
distractor_explanations.C: refers to a heterogeneous group of conditions of neonatal central nervous system dysfunction that results from ischemic injury. Patients may present with decreased Apgar scores, an abnormal state of consciousness, a weak cry, poor tone, respiratory distress, feeding difficulties, absent primitive reflexes, or seizures. Similarly, prenatal stroke (
distractor_explanations.E: refers to a heterogeneous group of primarily idiopathic stroke syndromes that may present with nonspecific symptoms such as drowsiness, crying, poor feeding, and seizure. Focal deficits such as torticollis and plagiocephaly are more consistent with birth trauma, and a mass of the SCM would be atypical. Left or right clavicle fractures (Choices D and
distractor_explanations.F: are the most common traumatic injuries during vaginal birth. Patients typically present with pain, swelling, and deformity along the affected clavicle. Syringobulbia (
distractor_explanations.H: refers to a rare condition involving a central cystic lesion of the brainstem. Patients typically present with lower cranial nerve and cerebellar signs along with involuntary movements such as torticollis and dystonia. Plagiocephaly and a mass of the SCM would be atypical.

explanation.educational_objective: Congenital torticollis typically presents in newborns with a preferred head position, decreased cervical range of motion, and a sternocleidomastoid muscle mass. Hypothesized causes include birth trauma (eg, forceps delivery) or intrauterine malposition of the head, which may lead to SCM injury and fibrosis. The fibrosis may present as a mass on physical examination. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Congenital torticollis typically presents in newborns with a preferred head position, decreased cervical range of motion, and a sternocleidomastoid muscle mass. Hypothesized causes include birth traum

vignette.presentation:
9. A previously healthy 7-year-old girl is admitted to the hospital because of an 11-day history of fever , fatigue , and progressive nonproductive cough . During the past 2 weeks , she has had a decreased appetite , resulting in a
1 .4-kg (3-lb) weight loss . The family lives on a farm in Missouri , and the patient often plays in an abandoned chicken coop . Her direct contact to animals is limited to a pet dog and turtle . She has not travelled outside of the state
during the past 9 months and has never been out of the USA. She appears alert . She is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F) , pulse is 110/min, respirations are 34/min , and blood
pressure is 96/57 mm Hg. Mild wheezes are heard bilaterally . The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities . Laboratory studies show :
Hemoglobin 12.3 g/dL
Leukocyte count 11 ,300/mm 3
Segmented neutrophils 48%
Bands 2%
Lymphocytes 46%
Monocytes 4%
Platelet count 210 ,000/mm 3
An x-ray and CT scan of the chest are shown . A blood culture obtained 4 days ago shows no growth . A PPD skin test performed 3 days ago shows no induration ; a mumps control skin test shows 8 mm of induration . A biopsy
specimen of a mediastinal lymph node shows necrotizing granulomas . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

distractor_explanations.A: and acute myelocytic leukemia (AML) (
distractor_explanations.B: are hematologic malignancies. ALL is more common in children than AML. The clinical presentations of both are similar, as they are caused by the relative burden of leukemic cells, including malaise, persistent fever, bleeding or bruising, bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. Neither would demonstrate necrotizing granulomas on lymph node biopsy. Chlamydia trachomatis infection (
distractor_explanations.C: can cause cervicitis, urethritis, pelvic inflammatory disease, neonatal pneumonia, and neonatal conjunctivitis. Other Chlamydia species, Chlamydophila pneumoniae and Chlamydophila psittaci, are causes of atypical pneumonia, which appear as diffuse, patchy alveolar and interstitial opacities on lung imaging. Q fever (
distractor_explanations.E: is a vector-borne illness caused by infection with Coxiella burnetii. Coxiella burnetii is acquired through the inhalation of spores from cattle or sheep amniotic fluid, to which this patient did not have exposure. Q fever commonly presents as pneumonia or endocarditis. Salmonella enteritidis infection (
distractor_explanations.F: causes nontyphoidal salmonellosis, a leading cause of food borne illness. It is contracted by the consumption of raw or undercooked poultry and eggs. Nausea, vomiting, and bloody diarrhea are classic features of salmonellosis. Tuberculosis (
distractor_explanations.G: is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, a slow-growing organism transmitted via respiratory droplets. It presents with primary, latent, and reactivation patterns. In primary disease, patients present with subacute fevers, weight loss, night sweats, cough, and malaise. A PPD, or tuberculin, test identifies exposure to tuberculosis and was negative in this case.

explanation.educational_objective: Histoplasmosis is an endemic fungal infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum. It is endemic to the Mississippi and Ohio River valleys in the United States; exposure to bird or bat droppings are risk factors. Pulmonary histoplasmosis can present in acute, subacute, or chronic phases, generally characterized by fevers, malaise, myalgia, cough, and hemoptysis with the associated development of small calcified nodules and mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Histoplasmosis is an endemic fungal infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum. It is endemic to the Mississippi and Ohio River valleys in the United States; exposure to bird or bat droppings are risk

vignette.presentation:
10. A 25-year-old woman , gravida 2, para 1, at 20 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. She feels well , and her pregnancy has been uncomplicated . Examination shows a uterus consistent in size with
a 20-week gestation . She reports that her first child had bloody diarrhea as an infant when he was fed cow milk-based formula . The diarrhea resolved when the formula was changed to a hypoallergenic type . She states that she
avoids dairy products because they upset her stomach . She asks how she can prevent food allergies in her next child . Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation ?

question_stem: the most appropriate recommendation ?

choices.text: Delay the introduction of solid food until the age of 9 months
Do not feed the infant eggs or peanut-based products until the age of 9 months
Exclusively breast-feed for at least 6 months
Use a hypoallergenic formula for at least 6 months
Use a lactose-free formula exclusively for at least 9 months

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Food allergies are a component of the atopic triad, which consists of atopic dermatitis, asthma, and food or environmental allergies. Food allergies may be immunoglobulin E (lgE)-mediated (eg, urticaria, angioedema, anaphylaxis) or non-lgE-mediated (eg, food protein-induced proctitis, proctocolitis, enterocolitis). Exclusive breast-feeding for at least 6 months is hypothesized to decrease the rate of food allergy in infants. Dietary avoidance of allergenic foods during pregnancy or lactation does not lead to decreased rates of food allergies in children. In actuality, introducing allergenic foods into the diet while lactating may lead to an increased likelihood of tolerance developing in the child and decreased rates of food allergy.

distractor_explanations.A: or delaying introduction of allergenic foods including eggs and peanut-based products (
distractor_explanations.B: until the age of 9 months has not been shown to decrease rates of food allergy. In contrast, the early introduction of allergenic foods has been recommended in order to improve tolerance to these foods. Use of a hypoallergenic formula for at least 6 months (
distractor_explanations.D: or a lactose-free formula for at least 9 months (
distractor_explanations.E: is not necessary nor shown to decrease food allergy development. In contrast, exclusive breast-feeding for at least 6 months is recommended. At 6 months, solid foods can begin to be introduced.

explanation.educational_objective: Exclusive breast-feeding for at least 6 months is hypothesized to decrease the rate of food allergy in infants. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Exclusive breast-feeding for at least 6 months is hypothesized to decrease the rate of food allergy in infants. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
12. A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of severe pain and swelling in her right sternoclavicular joint. Ten days ago , the patient had a sore throat. She has no history of serious illness and takes no
medications . Her temperature is 40°C (104 °F). Examination shows erythema , swelling , and tenderness of the right sternoclavicular joint. Aspiration of the affected joint yields thick , yellow , purulent fluid . A Gram stain of the fluid
shows numerous segmented neutrophils and numerous gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: CT scan of the left sternoclavicular joint

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient with monoarticular septic arthritis of the sternoclavicular joint from disseminated infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae should undergo arthrocentesis with culture of the aspirate fluid. Septic arthritis commonly occurs in children as a result of trauma to the joint permitting the translocation of cutaneous organisms (eg, Staphylococcus aureus) and may also occur in adolescents as a result of the dissemination of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a sexually transmitted bacterium that initially causes cervicitis, urethritis, or pharyngitis and may hematogenously disseminate to cause septic arthritis. Septic arthritis classically presents with a painful, erythematous, swollen joint along with systemic signs and symptoms of illness such as fever, chills, myalgia, arthralgia, and nausea. Gonococcal arthritis may present with monoarticular or asymmetric polyarticular disease and may feature adjacent tenosynovitis and dermatitis. The most common sites of gonococcal infection are the knee, ankle, wrist, and elbow, though the sternoclavicular joint may also be affected. In all causes of septic arthritis, serum laboratory values typically show leukocytosis along with increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein concentrations. Diagnosis requires arthrocentesis, which typically demonstrates purulent aspirate fluid with an increased concentration of neutrophil-predominant white blood cells. In gonococcal arthritis, culture of the aspirate fluid may disclose gram-negative diplococci. Management requires antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone and azithromycin along with source control.

distractor_explanations.B: may be used to detect late findings of underlying osteomyelitis (eg, erosions) in patients with septic arthritis caused by the translocation of cutaneous organisms such as Staphylococcus aureus. However, osteomyelitis is less likely to result from gonococcal arthritis. Echocardiography (
distractor_explanations.C: would be helpful in diagnosing gonococcal endocarditis, a rare complication of disseminated Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. However, this patient with symptoms localized to a joint most likely has gonococcal arthritis. CT scan of the left sternoclavicular joint (
distractor_explanations.D: may assist in the visualization of a joint effusion. This is especially true in difficult-to-examine joints such as the hip. However, joint aspiration is the preferred method for definitively diagnosing septic arthritis. Indium-labeled leukocyte scan (
distractor_explanations.E: , a nuclear medicine procedure that adds a radioactive tag to white blood cells, assists in localizing sites of infection and inflammation, and is often used in patients with a fever of unknown origin. This patient possesses a clear source of infection.

explanation.educational_objective: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a sexually transmitted bacterium that initially causes cervicitis, urethritis, or pharyngitis, and may hematogenously disseminate to cause septic arthritis. Gonococcal arthritis may present with monoarticular or asymmetric polyarticular erythema, edema, and tenderness. Diagnosis requires culture of the aspirate synovial fluid, which typically demonstrates gram-negative diplococci and an increased concentration of neutrophil-predominant white blood cells. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a sexually transmitted bacterium that initially causes cervicitis, urethritis, or pharyngitis, and may hematogenously disseminate to cause septic arthritis. Gonococcal arthrit

vignette.presentation:
13. A 5000-g (11-lb 1-oz) male infant is born at term to a 35-year-old woman following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. Initial examination shows that he is large for gestational age and has macroglossia , visceromegaly ,
and an omphalocele . This infant most likely has which of the following associated conditions?

question_stem: most likely has which of the following associated conditions?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is a genetic disorder involving mutations of any of several genes located at the 11p15.5 locus that may result from a variety of mechanisms, including defects of imprinting or uniparental disomy. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is characterized by cellular overgrowth and a predisposition to the development of malignancy. Its presentation is heterogenous but commonly includes an above average birth weight, macrosomia, macroglossia, visceromegaly, renal malformations, omphalocele, or umbilical hernia. Children with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are at an increased risk for developing a variety of malignancies, such as Wilms tumor and hepatoblastoma. Although the underlying mechanism is poorly understood, as many as half of children with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are affected by neonatal hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia. The diagnosis is confirmed with cytogenetic testing.

distractor_explanations.A: may occur as either an isolated anomaly or in association with a variety of syndromes, such as trisomy 21. Congenital heart defects are not commonly associated with Beckwith Wiedemann syndrome. lmperforate anus (
distractor_explanations.C: may occur either as a sporadic defect or as part of syndromic associations such as VACTERL (an association of findings characterized by vertebral anomalies, anorectal malformations, cardiovascular anomalies, tracheoesophageal fistula, esophageal atresia, renal anomalies, and limb defects). lmperforate anus is not commonly observed in association with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. Polycythemia (
distractor_explanations.D: may occur in association with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, but it is rare in comparison with hypoglycemia. Neonatal polycythemia commonly occurs in post-term infants and in infants with mothers affected by gestational diabetes mellitus. Renal tubular acidosis (
distractor_explanations.E: is a family of disorders that causes hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis and an inability to either absorb HCO -or excrete titratable acid in the form of NH Renal tubular acidosis is •. 3 4 not commonly associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

explanation.educational_objective: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is a heterogenous genetic disorder involving the 11p15.5 locus and is characterized by above average birth weight, macrosomia, macroglossia, visceromegaly, renal malformations, omphalocele, umbilical hernia, and an increased risk for malignancy such as Wilms tumor and hepatoblastoma. As many as half of children with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are affected by neonatal hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
14. A 9-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of headache and dizziness for the past week . She has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections . At the age of 2 years , she received the diagnosis of vesicoureteral reflux
and was treated with prophylactic amoxicillin until the age of 6 years . She has been admitted to the hospital twice for treatment of pyelonephritis . Development is appropriate for age , and her immunizations are up-to-date . Her
height and weight are below the 5th percentile . Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F) , pulse is 80/min , respirations are 16/min , and blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg in all four extremities . Funduscopic examination shows narrowing
of the retinal arteries . Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Follow-up blood pressure measurement in 1 week
Measurement of serum urea nitrogen and creatinine concentrations

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Measurement of serum urea nitrogen and creatinine concentrations is the most appropriate

distractor_explanations.A: is not appropriate at this time. The patient is presenting with symptoms, including headache and dizziness, that may be attributed to her hypertension. Further workup to determine the cause of her hypertension with simultaneous treatment is necessary. Blood cultures (
distractor_explanations.B: are not necessary. The patient is afebrile and has no flank pain or dysuria, making the diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis unlikely. Thyroid function tests (
distractor_explanations.D: are typically completed in the evaluation of secondary hypertension but would not be the first step. Hypothyroidism is more commonly associated with hypertension than hyperthyroidism, but patients also typically present with weight gain, constipation, fatigue, and cold intolerance. CT scan of the head (
distractor_explanations.E: should be considered in patients with focal neurologic deficits or severe, sudden onset headache, to rule out hemorrhagic stroke or subarachnoid hemorrhage. This patient has had a headache for 1 week and has no neurologic deficits reported; a CT scan would likely provide little additional diagnostic information and would not be the best

explanation.educational_objective: Chronic vesicoureteral reflux predisposes patients to recurrent pyelonephritis, which can result in scarring of the renal parenchyma and loss of nephron mass leading to chronic kidney disease. Impaired salt handling in chronic renal disease leads to expansion of the intravascular volume and subsequent hypertension. Laboratory evaluation should include the measurement of serum urea nitrogen and creatinine concentrations. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Chronic vesicoureteral reflux predisposes patients to recurrent pyelonephritis, which can result in scarring of the renal parenchyma and loss of nephron mass leading to chronic kidney disease. Impaire

vignette.presentation:
15. An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 4-day history of pallor. He has not had cough , rash , abdominal pain, vomiting , or diarrhea . He is alert but pale. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F) , pulse is 150/min ,
respirations are 36/min , and blood pressure is 90/72 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities . The stool is maroon , and test for occult blood is positive . His hemoglobin concentration is 8 g/dl. Which of the following is the
most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

distractor_explanations.A: is not sensitive for Meckel diverticulum. It is the first step in identifying a small bowel obstruction or ruling out gastrointestinal perforation but will not provide information about the cause of this patient's gastrointestinal bleeding. Upper gastrointestinal series (
distractor_explanations.B: refers to a series of upper abdominal x-rays taken after the administration of oral contrast. This allows for the visualization of the proximal gastrointestinal tract to assess for a variety of conditions, such as duodenal atresia, malrotation, and midgut volvulus, among others. A gastrointestinal series is unable to identify a Meckel diverticulum. HIDA scan (
distractor_explanations.C: is a nuclear medicine scan used to diagnose cholecystitis when ultrasound is indeterminate. This patient's symptoms are more consistent with a gastrointestinal bleed secondary to a Meckel diverticulum than cholecystitis. Anoscopy (
distractor_explanations.E: refers to a direct visualization technique of the anus and distal rectum. Anoscopy is used to visualize bleeding hemorrhoids, which is another cause of bright red bleed per rectum but does not typically cause a decrease in hemoglobin.

explanation.educational_objective: Meckel scan, or technetium 99m pertechnetate scan, is the modality used to confirm a Meckel diverticulum. A Meckel diverticulum is a small diverticulum projecting from the terminal ileum, which may contain ectopic gastric mucosa and lead to painless gastrointestinal bleeding. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Meckel scan, or technetium 99m pertechnetate scan, is the modality used to confirm a Meckel diverticulum. A Meckel diverticulum is a small diverticulum projecting from the terminal ileum, which may co

vignette.presentation:
16. A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the onset of confusion , decreased awareness , headache , weakness , and dyspnea . When his mother returned home from work , she found him sitting
in front of the television with the space heater on and an open package of cookies and glass of milk nearby. The most appropriate treatment is administration of which of the following?

question_stem: The most appropriate treatment is administration of which of the following?

distractor_explanations.A: is the principal antidote for acetaminophen toxicity. Acetaminophen, in toxic doses, overwhelms phase II metabolic pathways (eg, sulfation, acetylation) with consequent depletion of glutathione stores; excess is metabolized to the toxic metabolite N-acetyl-P-benzoquinoneimine, a strong oxidant. Acetylcysteine regenerates hepatic glutathione stores, limiting oxidative damage. Amyl nitrite (
distractor_explanations.B: is an antidote for cyanide poisoning; nitrites induce the formation of methemoglobin, which in turn sequesters cyanide as cyanomethemoglobin, preventing its disruption of the electron transport chain. Its use is less frequent, as cobalamin also sequesters cyanide without interfering with hemoglobin and oxygen-carrying capacity. Atropine (
distractor_explanations.C: is an antidote for organophosphate poisoning and is a cholinergic antagonist. Organophosphate toxicity is common in the developing world; organophosphates bind to the active site of acetylcholinesterase, preventing the breakdown of acetylcholine. Resultant cholinergic excess leads to bronchospasm, bronchorrhea, bradycardia, diarrhea, lacrimation, and salivation. Atropine reverses the impact of cholinergic excess on the heart and lungs. Deferoxamine (
distractor_explanations.D: is an antidote for iron toxicity, which can be fatal in excess as a consequence of hepatic failure and profound metabolic acidosis. Dimercaprol (BAL) (
distractor_explanations.E: is an antidote commonly used to treat arsenic and mercury poisoning, though it additionally chelates lead and gold in serum. Methylene blue (
distractor_explanations.F: is an antidote for methemoglobinemia; it serves to decrease iron in methemoglobin to Fe 2 restoring its ability to bind and transport oxygen. Methemoglobinemia may occur secondary to •, the use of nitrites and anesthetics. Naloxone (
distractor_explanations.G: is an opioid receptor antagonist used in the treatment of opiate overdose, which presents with bradypnea and miosis. Naloxone has also been used to treat clonidine overdose. r " , r-- r ,

explanation.educational_objective: CO has an affinity for hemoglobin that is hundreds of times greater than that of oxygen, readily displacing oxygen from heme. Treatment for CO poisoning begins with the administration of 100% oxygen. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: CO has an affinity for hemoglobin that is hundreds of times greater than that of oxygen, readily displacing oxygen from heme. Treatment for CO poisoning begins with the administration of 100% oxygen.

vignette.presentation:
17. A previously healthy 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 4-month history of progressive fatigue and nervousness , intermittent blurred vision , and declining school performance . She has had a 3-kg (6.6-lb)
weight loss during this period despite an increased appetite . Her sister has hypothyroidism treated with levothyroxine . The patient's temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 120/min , respirations are 18/min , and blood pressure is
110/80 mm Hg. Examination shows warm flushed skin and fine soft hair. There is mild exophthalmos and lid lag. Funduscopic examination and visual fields show no abnormalities . Examination of the neck shows an enlarged
thyroid gland with a bruit. There is a fine tremor when her upper extremities are outstretched . Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's findings?

choices.text: Lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid gland
Malignant infiltration of the thyroid gland

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Graves disease is an autoimmune hyperthyroid condition caused by thyroid-stimulating autoantibodies that activate the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor. Hyperstimulation of the TSH receptor leads to overproduction of thyroid hormone and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland on physical examination, along with signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism including weight loss, insomnia, palpitations, heat intolerance, warm skin, tremor, diaphoresis, and pretibial myxedema. TSH-receptor-stimulating antibodies also stimulate orbital fibroblasts and lead to thyroid ophthalmopathy, which is characterized by the expansion of orbital fat and connective tissue with resultant exophthalmos, lid lag, and restrictive strabismus. Thyroid ophthalmopathy may lead to diplopia, corneal exposure, compressive optic neuropathy, and a cosmetic appearance that is distressing for patients. Thyroid laboratory studies typically demonstrate primary hyperthyroidism with increased thyroxine and triiodothyronine, and decreased TSH. Radioactive iodine uptake nuclear scintigraphy typically demonstrates diffuse, abnormally increased uptake of the thyroid gland without a discrete nodule. Graves disease is treated with antithyroid drugs such as methimazole and propylthiouracil, and radioactive iodine ablation of the thyroid gland. Thyroid ophthalmopathy typically responds well to topical lubrication, although severe cases may require intravenous corticosteroids and a staged surgical approach.

distractor_explanations.A: may present with signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism including tachycardia, hypertension, tremor, and anxiety. Severe cases may cause convulsions and coma. This patient's history of progressive symptoms over a four-month period, as well as her symptoms of exophthalmos and lid lag, are not consistent with an overdose event. Lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid gland (
distractor_explanations.B: is characteristic of Hashimoto disease. While patients with Hashimoto disease may present with transient symptoms of hyperthyroidism during the acute stage, patients progress to develop signs and symptoms of hypothyroidism, including fatigue, cold intolerance, weight gain, hyporeflexia, myxedema, and dry, cool skin. Hashimoto disease does not cause orbital findings of exophthalmos and lid lag. Malignant infiltration of the thyroid gland (
distractor_explanations.C: may lead to symptoms of hyperthyroidism through the destruction of thyroid follicular cells with resultant release of thyroid hormone, though patients are generally euthyroid. This mechanism would not cause orbital findings of exophthalmos and lid lag. Thyroid-stimulating hormone-producing pituitary tumor (
distractor_explanations.D: would lead to hyperthyroidism and laboratory findings of an increased serum concentration of TSH, as well as thyroid hormone.

explanation.educational_objective: Graves disease is an autoimmune hyperthyroid condition caused by thyroid-stimulating antibodies that activate the TSH receptor. Overproduction of thyroid hormone causes signs and symptoms of weight loss, insomnia, palpitations, heat intolerance, warm skin, tremor, diaphoresis, and pretibial myxedema. The presence of thyroid eye disease, characterized by exophthalmos, lid lag, and restrictive strabismus, is highly suggestive of Graves disease. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Graves disease is an autoimmune hyperthyroid condition caused by thyroid-stimulating antibodies that activate the TSH receptor. Overproduction of thyroid hormone causes signs and symptoms of weight lo

vignette.presentation:
18. A 2807-g (6-lb 3-oz) newborn has a strong cry immediately after delivery . She was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and a spontaneous vaginal delivery complicated by a few decelerations . The newborn was
suctioned at the perineum and placed on the warmer/resuscitation table . After 10 seconds of warming , the newborn's pulse is greater than 100/min , and respirations are 20/min . Examination shows peripheral cyanosis and
minimal movement of the upper and lower extremities . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The initiation of breathing following delivery is crucial for the newborn. A substantial portion of neonates require assistance with the initiation of breathing. Initial, universal steps after delivery include an assessment of the newborn's heart and respiratory rates, muscle tone, reflexes, and color, and immediate warming, drying, and tactile stimulation, all of which are helpful for stimulating spontaneous respirations. Neonates who fail to respond to gentle tactile stimulation should be immediately supported with more invasive support techniques, such as bag and mask ventilation or endotracheal intubation. Tactile stimulation and oxygen therapy are noninvasive and are therefore an appropriate initial step.

distractor_explanations.B: may be useful for the immediate reversal of opioid toxicity in neonates. This neonate does not have any known risk factors for opioid toxicity and tactile stimulation is a more appropriate

explanation.educational_objective: Many neonates require assistance with the initiation of spontaneous respirations. Tactile stimulation and oxygen therapy are noninvasive and decreases neonatal morbidity and mortality. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Many neonates require assistance with the initiation of spontaneous respirations. Tactile stimulation and oxygen therapy are noninvasive and decreases neonatal morbidity and mortality. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
19. A 2-week-old female newborn is brought to the physician because of bruising on her arms and legs for 2 days . She was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy . The delivery was precipitous , but the newborn fed well
soon after birth . Examination shows petechiae over the face and trunk , scattered ecchymoses over the extremities , and an erythematous , fleshy irregular mass on the thigh . A bruit is heard over the hepatic area . Laboratory
studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13 g/dL , leukocyte count of 5000/mm 3 and platelet count of 15,000/mm 3 Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
, .

question_stem:
the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
, .

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Large vascular neoplasms, or hemangiomas, including tufted angioma and kaposiform hemangioendothelioma, are associated with a consumptive coagulopathy characterized by severe thrombocytopenia and decrease in fibrinogen and other coagulation factors called Kasabach-Merritt syndrome. These neoplasms present as red or purple subcutaneous tumors. The increased blood flow may cause the affected area to be warm and swollen or even cause a limb length discrepancy. Signs of other hemangiomas, such as a bruit over the liver, may also be present. The large, convoluted vascular architecture causes platelet adhesion and trapping. This trapping leads to consumption offibrinogen and ongoing fibrinolysis, causing a consumptive coagulopathy. Patients present, as in this case, with mucocutaneous bleeding (bruising and petechiae), which could not be explained by trauma. They also demonstrate thrombocytopenia on laboratory evaluation. Treatment includes supportive measures to maintain hemostasis and treatment of the underlying vascular neoplasm.

distractor_explanations.A: has a variety of presentations. It is rare in children, particularly in newborns. The most common type of cutaneous lymphoma is mycosis fungoides, an indolent cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. Mycosis fungoides presents with scaly, wrinkled patches in sun-protected areas, more often in adults than children. Cystic hygroma (
distractor_explanations.B: and lymphangioma (
distractor_explanations.E: are both lymphatic malformations. Cystic hygroma may be seen in association with Turner syndrome as a subcutaneous mass of the neck. However, neither of these are associated with Kasabach-Merritt syndrome or the development of thrombocytopenia. Juvenile xanthogranuloma (
distractor_explanations.D: is an uncommon benign proliferation of histiocytes. It clinically appears as a solitary orange-pink papule on the face, neck, or trunk of a child. It is not a vascular neoplasm and does not cause Kasabach-Merritt syndrome. Mastocytoma (
distractor_explanations.F: is a benign proliferation of mast cells in the skin. The typical presentation is a single, orange-brown, leathery plaque, which forms a wheal upon scratching. Mastocytosis may also have presentations without cutaneous findings. Rapid mast cell degranulation may cause anaphylaxis but does not contribute to thrombocytopenia. Neurofibroma (
distractor_explanations.G: is characteristic of neurofibromatosis, a genetically inherited disorder characterized by a constellation of cutaneous manifestations including neurofibromas, plexiform neurofibromas, cafe-au lait macules, and axillary freckling, none of which are present in this patient. Thrombocytopenia is not a typical clinical finding.

explanation.educational_objective: Kasabach-Merritt syndrome is a consumptive coagulopathy in which a large, convoluted vascular neoplasm traps platelets and then activates fibrinogen and fibrinolysis. It is seen in association with tufted angioma and kaposiform hemangioendothelioma, both of which are hemangiomas that may be present at or shortly after birth. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Kasabach-Merritt syndrome is a consumptive coagulopathy in which a large, convoluted vascular neoplasm traps platelets and then activates fibrinogen and fibrinolysis. It is seen in association with tu

vignette.presentation:
20. A previously healthy 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of progressive hair loss over the past 4 weeks . Examination shows a swollen and purulent area on the scalp . A photograph
is shown . The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp common in children. The most common presentation is scaly patches with alopecia. The patches of alopecia may demonstrate black dots that represent broken hairs. When a significant inflammatory response to the fungal infection occurs, a kerion develops. A kerion is a boggy and swollen lesion on examination. Tinea capitis is caused by dermatophytes including Trichophyton rubrum, Epidermophyton floccosum, and Microsporum canis. First-line treatment of tinea capitis is with an oral antifungal, usually griseofulvin or terbinafine. Close contacts of patients should be examined as the condition is contagious and can be spread through fomites, such as shared combs, pillows, or hats.

distractor_explanations.A: will worsen tinea capitis by inhibiting the inflammatory response necessary to eliminate the infection. Superficial dermatophyte infections treated with topical corticosteroids may become more severe. Tinea treated with topical corticosteroids is often referred to as tinea incognito, because of the severe and unusual morphologies that these infections take on after treatment with topical corticosteroids. Tinea capitis is a fungal infection, not a bacterial infection, and thus oral antibacterial therapy (
distractor_explanations.B: is unnecessary. Tinea capitis and kerion may become secondarily colonized with skin flora, such as S. aureus, in which case antibiotics may be necessary, but this is atypical. Oral antibacterial therapy is appropriate for bacterial skin infections including cellulitis, erysipelas, and severe folliculitis. Surgical excision (
distractor_explanations.D: is unnecessary as the infection can be treated with oral antifungals. In children, dermatologic surgical excision is generally reserved for neoplastic processes. No intervention necessary (
distractor_explanations.E: is not the standard of care for tinea capitis. Without appropriate antifungal treatment, the infection and inflammatory response will worsen. Inadequate treatment puts the patient's close contacts at risk for developing the infection as well.

explanation.educational_objective: Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp common in children. When a significant inflammatory response to the fungal infection occurs, a kerion develops. First-line treatment of tinea capitis includes an oral antifungal, usually griseofulvin or terbinafine, along with the treatment of close contacts, if necessary. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp common in children. When a significant inflammatory response to the fungal infection occurs, a kerion develops. First-line treatment of tinea capitis i

vignette.presentation:
22. A full-term 24-hour-old newborn has respiratory distress and seizures . Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes , respectively . An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse hazy infiltrates bilaterally . Leukocyte count is
12,500/mm 3 (65% segmented neutrophils and 10% bands) . Examination of cerebrospinal fluid shows 4 leukocytes/mm 3 (90% lymphocytes) , a glucose concentration of 75 mg/dL , and a protein concentration of 25 mg/dl. Which
of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Neonatal sepsis is categorized often on the basis of time from parturition, since the period of time in which symptoms begin may indicate which pathogen is likely involved, thereby guiding therapy. Early-onset neonatal sepsis (within 72 hours of birth) is marked by symptoms of lethargy, seizures, poor feeding, weak cry, and hypotonia. It presents with tachycardia, tachypnea, occasionally fever, and often with an examination that is nonfocal. If examination findings are present, they may reflect the source of infection or may reflect complications of sepsis such as neonatal respiratory distress syndrome. Early-onset neonatal sepsis generally occurs as a result of pathogens acquired from the mother, either through hematogenous or transplacental spread or, commonly, contact acquisition in the birth canal. The most common pathogens associated with early-onset neonatal sepsis include Streptococcus agalactiae (group B), Escherichia coli, coagulase-negative Staphylococcus, and Listeria monocytogenes. Syndromes of serious bacterial infection include bacteremia, meningitis, and pneumonia. Late-onset neonatal sepsis (presenting 72 hours or more after birth) more commonly occurs from environmental pathogens in addition to those acquired from the mother. Pneumonia is more common in early-onset sepsis, and presents with cough, tachypnea, tachycardia, hypoxia, increased work of breathing, and rhonchi on auscultation. Workup for any suspected case of sepsis in a child younger than 30 days of age is broad, and should include a complete blood count, urinalysis, blood cultures, chest x-ray, and lumbar puncture at a minimum, since symptoms in this population are vague and nonspecific, limiting the utility of the history and physical examination to guide workup. X-rays in neonatal pneumonia disclose focal or diffuse airspace disease or may show diffuse interstitial infiltrates suggestive of respiratory distress syndrome. Treatment includes broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover the common pathogens.

distractor_explanations.B: , E. coli, coagulase-negative Staphylococcus, and L monocytogenes. Pneumocystis jiroveci (formerly P. carini1) pneumonia (
distractor_explanations.C: most commonly occurs in adults, whereas common pathogens causing meningitis in the neonate include Streptococcus agalactiae (group
distractor_explanations.D: generally occurs in immunocompromised persons and was seen commonly in individuals with advanced HIV prior to the use of prophylactic antibiotics. Patients classically present with cough, fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypoxia, with rhonchi on lung auscultation and prominent perihilar and multifocal infiltrates on chest x-ray. It would be rare in a neonate. Respiratory syncytial virus pneumonia (
distractor_explanations.E: is one of the most common causes of bronchiolitis and pneumonia in children younger than 2 years of age. In the neonatal period, bacterial infection is more common and is also more consistent with bandemia and diffuse infiltrates on x-ray.

explanation.educational_objective: Common causes of early neonatal sepsis include Streptococcus agalactiae (group B), E. coli, and L monocytogenes, which are generally acquired during birth from the mother. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Common causes of early neonatal sepsis include Streptococcus agalactiae (group B), E. coli, and L monocytogenes, which are generally acquired during birth from the mother. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:

stimuli. He has a grade 3/6 systolic murmur with a gallop and diffuse abdominal tenderness . Laboratory studies show :

HCO - 15 mEq/L
